title: Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash-Equilibria

sections.text:
#### Abstract

We study partial information Nash equilibrium between a broker and an informed trader. In this setting, the informed trader, who possesses knowledge of a trading signal, trades multiple assets with the broker in a dealer market. Simultaneously, the broker offloads these assets in a lit exchange where their actions impact the asset prices. The broker, however, only observes aggregate prices and cannot distinguish between underlying trends and volatility. Both the broker and the informed trader aim to maximize their penalized expected wealth. Using convex analysis, we characterize the Nash equilibrium and demonstrate its existence and uniqueness. Furthermore, we establish that this equilibrium corresponds to the solution of a nonstandard system of forward-backward stochastic differential equations (FBSDEs) that involves the two differing filtrations. For short enough time horizons, we prove that a unique solution of this system exists. Finally, under quite general assumptions, we show that the solution to the FBSDE system admits a polynomial approximation in the strength of the transient impact to arbitrary order, and prove that the error is controlled.


Keywords Nash equilibrium $\cdot$ trading signals $\cdot$ partial information $\cdot$ differing filtrations $\cdot$ FBSDE

## 1 Introduction

In this article, we study the Nash equilibrium between a broker and their client (an informed trader) in a partial information setting. The informed trader trades multiple assets with the Broker in an over-the-counter market, while the Broker also trades in a lit exchange where their trading activities have both transient and instantaneous impact on the prices in the lit market as in the diagram below ${ }^{2}$.
![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Figure 1: Blue print of how informed trader and broker interact with each other and the lit market.

[^0]
[^0]:    *SJ acknowledges support from the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada (RGPIN-2024-04317, RGPIN-2018-05705)
    ${ }^{2}$ While the diagram shows noise traders who interact with the broker, we omit them from our analysis as they do not add any additional insights to the problem setting.

# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

The informed trader has privy to a private trading signal about the assets' drifts, while the Broker does not. Our setup is similar to the one in [9], where the authors study a setting with an informed trader and Broker trading a single asset and both have access to the market's full information, including the asset's stochastic drift as a private trading signal. Our setup differs from [9] in two key aspects. Firstly, instead of only trading a single asset, we consider trading multiple (correlated or even co-integrated) assets. Secondly, we assume the broker has access only to asset prices rather than the full market information. Both the broker and the informed trader aim to maximize their (penalized) expected wealth from trading activities over a fixed time horizon by choosing trading strategies based on their respective information content. This leads to a partial information setting for the Broker, but a full information setting for the informed trader.

We use variational methods to characterize the optimal response of each agent. Based on this optimal response, we prove uniqueness and existence of Nash equilibrium between the broker and the informed trader in the small time setting. As a result, we obtain a filtered system of forward-backward stochastic differential equations (FBSDEs) that characterizes the Nash equilibrium.

One of the earliest works on partial information equilibria in the trading setting is the seminal work of [22], who studies how a market marker (MM) sets prices in the presence of noise traders and an informed trader who has a private signal (not available to the MM) regarding the future price of an asset. Other early works on partial information include [20], who study optimal portfolio allocation with latent Ornstein-Uhlenbeck returns and [23] who study model uncertainty in the context of portfolio optimization and the optimal allocation of assets. More recently, and more directly related to this study, [19] studies optimal trading in a discrete-time, infinite-time horizon setting, where there is an unpredictable martingale component, and an independent stationary (visible) predictable component - the alpha component. The question of how trading signals affect market making decisions is studied in [11], while [15] studies how differing trading signals alter trading decisions. The role that stochastic price impact plays on optimal trading with trading signal is investigated by [17]. Further, [16] proposes models for optimal execution when the drift is estimated/filtered from prices. The case of trading signals with general transient impact kernels is investigated by [1]. [5] studies the optimal execution problem when stochastic price impact of market orders and the arrival rates of limit and market orders are functions of the market liquidity process and [7] incorporates contextual bandit algorithms into trading decisions.

Furthermore, [13] analyze how to optimally trade with latent factors that cause prices to jump and diffuse in a single-trader model. Motivated by [13], [12] generalizes the model by considering a large collection of heterogeneous agents and combines Nash equilibrium and partial information setting. [14] further extends [12] by incorporating differing model beliefs among the agents. As in [12] and [14], here we use a convex analysis approach and characterize the equilibrium as solution of FBSDE. In contrast to these earlier works, in our setting the broker and the informed trader have different filtrations on which their strategies are adapted.

In addition to equilibrium and partial filtration, this paper ties into the field of optimal trading strategies with market signals. There are several studies in this line of research. The early work of [8] derives an optimal execution strategy when the order-flow from market participants influences both midprices and execution costs - order-flow in their paper induces a trading signal. [10] studies a broker-trader model where the broker uses the informed trader's flow to learn price signals and derives optimal strategy which combines inventory management and signal-driven speculation. [6] combines filtering theory to estimate unobserved toxicity and variational methods in the unwinding of order flow. Contemporaneous to the first version of this paper, [3] study a related setting involving an informed trader (with a Gaussian signal) and a broker. They do so in Stackelberg like setting, and assume from the outset that the broker uses a Kalman-Bucy filter to filter the trading signal. In contrast, we provide precise mathematical characterization of the Nash equilibria without making such assumptions and do so in the multi-dimensional setting.

The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. In section 2, we introduce the notations, the model, and the performance criteria. In section 3, we show that the broker's and the informed trader's performance criteria are strictly concave functionals in terms of their respective trading strategies, and compute the Gâteaux-derivatives of the criteria. Finally, in section 4, we characterize the Nash equilibrium as the solution of a filtered system of FBSDEs and prove its existence and uniqueness for small time horizon. Moreover, we develop an asymptotic expansion of the solution to

# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

the FBSDEs, in terms of the strength of the transient impact parameter to arbitrary order, and prove that the error is controlled.

## 2 The Broker-Trader Setting

In this section, we introduce the underlying system dynamics, as well as the broker's and the informed trader's performance criteria. Of particular note is the differing filtrations that the two agents have.

Unimpacted price model: Let $T \in(0, \infty)$ be a given time horizon. We fix a complete filtered probability space $(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mathbb{F}, \mathbb{P})$ where the filtration $\mathbb{F}=\left(\mathcal{F}_{t}\right)_{t \in[0, T]}$ satisfies the usual conditions of completeness and right-continuity. $\mathbb{F}$ represents the full market information. Let $W$ be an $\mathbb{F}$-Brownian motion. The unimpacted asset price $z$ (i.e., the price if the broker does not send any orders to the lit market) satisfies the stochastic differential equation (SDE)

$$
\mathrm{d} z_{t}=\alpha_{t} \mathrm{~d} t+\sigma_{t} \mathrm{~d} W_{t}
$$

where $z_{0} \in L^{2}\left(\mathcal{F}_{0}\right)$, the drift coefficient $\alpha$ is an $\mathbb{R}^{K}$-valued $\mathbb{F}$-progressively measurable process satisfying $\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|\alpha_{t}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} t\right]<\infty$ and represents a private trading signal, and the diffusion coefficient $\sigma$ is an $\mathbb{R}^{K \times D}$-valued bounded $\mathbb{F}$-progressively measurable process, i.e., there exists $L \in \mathbb{R}$ such that

$$
\left|\sigma_{t}(\omega)\right| \leq L \text { for all }(\omega, t) \in \Omega \times[0, T]
$$

We assume the informed trader has access to the full market information, so they trade strategically by choosing a strategy from the set of admissible strategies

$$
\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}:=\left\{\eta: \Omega \times[0, T] \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{K} \mid \eta \text { is } \mathbb{F} \text {-progressively measurable and } \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|\eta_{t}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} t\right]<\infty\right\}
$$

Note that, equipped with the norm $\|\eta\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}:=\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|\eta_{t}\right|^{2}\right] \mathrm{d} t\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}, \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$ is precisely $L^{2}(\Omega \times[0, T], \mathcal{P}, \mathbb{P} \otimes \lambda)$, where $\mathcal{P}$ is the $\sigma$-algebra on $\Omega \times[0, T]$ generated by $\mathbb{F}$-progressively measurable processes and $\lambda$ is the Lebesgue measure on $[0, T]$, thus, it is a Hilbert space. In the remainder of this paper, the informed trader's trading strategy is denoted by the symbol $\eta \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$, if not otherwise specified.

Contrastingly, we assume the broker observes the prices of all assets in the lit market, and only this information may be used to control their trading strategy with the lit exchange. This information is modeled by the minimal enlargement $\mathbb{G}=\left(\mathcal{G}_{t}\right)_{t \in[0, T]}$ of the natural filtration generated by $z$ to ensure the usual conditions, i.e.,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{G}_{t} & =\bigcap_{s>t}\left(\sigma\left(z_{u}: 0 \leq u \leq s\right) \vee \mathcal{N}\right), \quad t \in[0, T) \\
\mathcal{G}_{T} & =\sigma\left(z_{u}: 0 \leq u \leq T\right) \vee \mathcal{N}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathcal{N}$ is the collection of all $\mathbb{P}$-null sets. The broker's set of admissible trading strategies is

$$
\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}:=\left\{\nu: \Omega \times[0, T] \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{K} \mid \nu \text { is } \mathbb{G} \text {-progressively measurable and }\|\nu\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}<\infty\right\}
$$

Note, $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$ is a closed subspace of $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$. In the remainder of this paper, the broker's trading strategy is denoted by the symbol $\nu \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$, if not otherwise specified.
Transient price impact model: The broker's trading activity in the lit exchange has transient impact on the asset price, which we denote $Y$ and whose dynamics is assumed ${ }^{3}$ to be:

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{d} Y_{t}^{\nu} & =\left(h \nu_{t}-p Y_{t}^{\nu}\right) \mathrm{d} t \\
Y_{0}^{\nu} & =y
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

where $y \in L^{2}\left(\mathcal{G}_{0}\right), p$ and $h$ are $K \times K$ constant positive semi-definite matrices representing decay coefficients and instantaneous impact parameters, respectively. We further assume $p$ and $h$ commute.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{3}$ We remark, that this exponential decay can be relaxed to non-exponential kernels with some additional care, but as in this paper we wish to focus on the effect that the partial information has, we remain within this simpler setting.

# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

The process $Y$ admits the explicit representation as

$$
Y_{t}^{\nu}=\mathrm{e}^{-t p} y+\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{e}^{(s-t) p} h \nu_{s} \mathrm{~d} s
$$

Equipped with the unimpacted price model (2.1) and the transient impact price model (2.3), the midprice process $S$ is given by

$$
S_{t}^{\nu}=Y_{t}^{\nu}+z_{t}
$$

Broker's Inventory and Cash: The broker's inventory process $Q^{B, \nu, \eta}$ and cash process $X^{B, \nu, \eta}$ are given by

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{d} Q_{t}^{B, \nu, \eta} & =\left(\nu_{t}-\eta_{t}\right) \mathrm{d} t \\
Q_{0}^{B, \nu, \eta} & =q^{B}
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

where $q^{B} \in L^{2}\left(\mathcal{F}_{0}\right)$, and

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{d} X_{t}^{B, \nu, \eta} & =\left(-\left(S_{t}^{\nu}+a \nu_{t}\right)^{\top} \nu_{t}+\left(S_{t}^{\nu}+b \eta_{t}\right)^{\top} \eta_{t}\right) \mathrm{d} t \\
X_{0}^{B, \nu, \eta} & =x^{B}
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

where $x^{B} \in L^{2}\left(\mathcal{F}_{0}\right), a$ and $b$ are $K \times K$ constant positive definite matrices representing stylized instantaneous transaction costs incurred by the broker (when trading with the lit market) and the informed trader (when trading with the broker), respectively.
Informed trader's Inventory and Cash: The informed trader's inventory process $Q^{I, \eta}$ and cash process $X^{I, \nu, \eta}$ are given by

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{d} Q_{t}^{I, \eta} & =\eta_{t} \mathrm{~d} t \\
Q_{0}^{I, \eta} & =q^{I}
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

where $q^{I} \in L^{2}\left(\mathcal{F}_{0}\right)$, and

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{d} X_{t}^{I, \nu, \eta} & =-\left(S_{t}^{\nu}+b \eta_{t}\right)^{\top} \eta_{t} \mathrm{~d} t \\
X_{0}^{I, \nu, \eta} & =x^{I}
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

where $x^{I} \in L^{2}\left(\mathcal{F}_{0}\right)$.
We denote by $\|A\|$ the operator norm of the matrix $A$. Recall that if $A$ is a positive semi-definite matrix and $t \leq 0$, then $\left\|\mathrm{e}^{t A}\right\| \leq 1$.
Lemma 2.1. $Y^{\nu} \in \mathbb{H}_{G}^{2} . Q^{B, \nu, \eta}, Q^{I, \eta} \in \mathbb{H}_{P}^{2} . S^{\nu}$ is a continuous $\mathbb{F}$-semimartingale. $Q^{B, \nu, \eta}, X^{B, \nu, \eta}, Q^{I, \eta}, X^{I, \nu, \eta}$ are $\mathbb{F}$-adapted continuous finite variation processes.

Proof. As $\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|\nu_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s\right]<\infty$,

$$
\int_{0}^{t}\left|\mathrm{e}^{(s-t) p} h \nu_{s}\right| \mathrm{d} s \leq \int_{0}^{t}\left\|\mathrm{e}^{(s-t) p}\right\|\|h\|\left|\nu_{s}\right| \mathrm{d} s \leq\|h\| t^{1 / 2}\left(\int_{0}^{t}\left|\nu_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s\right)^{1 / 2}<\infty, \quad \forall t \in[0, T] \text { a.s. }
$$

Since $\nu$ is $\mathbb{G}$-progressively measurable, (2.7) implies $Y^{\nu}$ is a $\mathbb{G}$-adapted continuous finite variation process, which is $\mathbb{G}$-progressively measurable. (2.7) also implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|Y_{t}^{\nu}\right|^{2} \leq\left(\left\|\mathrm{e}^{-t p}\right\||y|+\int_{0}^{t}\left|\mathrm{e}^{(s-t) p} h \nu_{s}\right| \mathrm{d} s\right)^{2} & \leq\left(|y|+\|h\| t^{1 / 2}\left(\int_{0}^{t}\left|\nu_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s\right)^{1 / 2}\right)^{2} \\
& \leq 2\left(|y|^{2}+\|h\|^{2} t \int_{0}^{t}\left|\nu_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

$$
\leq 2\left(|y|^{2}+T\|h\|^{2} \int_{0}^{T}\left|\nu_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s\right) \quad \forall t \in[0, T]
$$

so

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|Y_{t}^{\nu}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} t\right] \leq 2 T\left(\mathbb{E}\left[|y|^{2}\right]+T\|h\|^{2}\|\nu\|_{\mathbb{R}}^{2}\right)<\infty
$$

therefore, $Y^{\nu} \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{D}}^{2}$. Since $\alpha \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$ and $\sigma$ is bounded $\mathbb{F}$-progressively measurable, $z$ is a continuous $\mathbb{F}$-semimartingale. Consequently, $S^{\nu}$ is a continuous $\mathbb{F}$-semimartingale. By continuity of the sample paths of $S^{\nu}$ and the fact that $\nu, \eta \in$ $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{0}^{t}\left|-\left(S_{s}^{\nu}+a \nu_{s}\right)^{\top} \nu_{s}+\left(S_{s}^{\nu}+b \eta_{s}\right)^{\top} \eta_{s}\right| \mathrm{d} s \\
& \leq \int_{0}^{t}\left(\left(\left|S_{s}^{\nu}\right|+\|a\| \| \nu_{s}\right)\left|\nu_{s}\right|+\left(\left|S_{s}^{\nu}\right|+\|b\| \| \eta_{s}\right)\left|\eta_{s}\right|\right) \mathrm{d} s \\
& \leq\left(\int_{0}^{t}\left|S_{s}^{\nu}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s\right)^{1 / 2}\left(\left(\int_{0}^{t}\left|\nu_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s\right)^{1 / 2}+\left(\int_{0}^{t}\left|\eta_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s\right)^{1 / 2}\right)+\|a\| \int_{0}^{t}\left|\nu_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s+\|b\| \int_{0}^{t}\left|\eta_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s<\infty
\end{aligned}
$$

for all $t \in[0, T]$, a.s., thus $X^{B, \nu, \eta}$ is an $\mathbb{F}$-adapted continuous finite variation processes. Similarly, $X^{I, \nu, \eta}$ is an $\mathbb{F}$-adapted continuous finite variation processes.

On the other hand,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{0}^{t}\left|\nu_{s}-\eta_{s}\right| \mathrm{d} s & \leq \int_{0}^{t}\left|\nu_{s}\right| \mathrm{d} s+\int_{0}^{t}\left|\eta_{s}\right| \mathrm{d} s \\
& \leq t^{1 / 2}\left(\left(\int_{0}^{t}\left|\nu_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s\right)^{1 / 2}+\left(\int_{0}^{t}\left|\eta_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s\right)^{1 / 2}\right)<\infty, \quad \forall t \in[0, T] \text { a.s. }
\end{aligned}
$$

meaning $Q^{B, \nu, \eta}$ is an $\mathbb{F}$-adapted continuous finite variation process, which is $\mathbb{F}$-progressively measurable. (2.8) also implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|Q_{t}^{B, \nu, \eta}\right|^{2} \leq\left(\left|q^{B}\right|+\int_{0}^{t}\left|\nu_{s}-\eta_{s}\right| \mathrm{d} s\right)^{2} & \leq\left(\left|q^{B}\right|+t^{1 / 2}\left(\left(\int_{0}^{t}\left|\nu_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s\right)^{1 / 2}+\left(\int_{0}^{t}\left|\eta_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s\right)^{1 / 2}\right)\right)^{2} \\
& \leq 3\left(\left|q^{B}\right|^{2}+t\left(\int_{0}^{t}\left|\nu_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s+\int_{0}^{t}\left|\eta_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s\right)\right) \\
& \leq 3\left(\left|q^{B}\right|^{2}+T\left(\int_{0}^{T}\left|\nu_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s+\int_{0}^{T}\left|\eta_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

so

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|Q_{t}^{B, \nu, \eta}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} t\right] \leq 3 T\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\left|q^{B}\right|^{2}\right]+T\left(\|\nu\|_{\mathbb{R}}^{2}+\|\eta\|_{\mathbb{R}}^{2}\right)\right)<\infty
$$

therefore, $Q^{B, \nu, \eta} \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$. Similarly, $Q^{I, \eta}$ is an $\mathbb{F}$-adapted continuous finite variation process and $Q^{I, \eta} \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$.
Performance Criteria: The informed trader's and the broker's performance criteria are denoted $J^{I}(\nu, \eta)$ and $J^{B}(\nu, \eta)$, respectively, and are given by

$$
J^{I}(\nu, \eta)=\mathbb{E}\left[X_{T}^{I, \eta}+\left(S_{T}^{\nu}-\psi Q_{T}^{I, \eta}\right)^{\top} Q_{T}^{I, \eta}-\int_{0}^{T}\left(Q_{t}^{I, \eta}\right)^{\top} r^{I} Q_{t}^{I, \eta} \mathrm{~d} t\right]
$$

and

$$
J^{B}(\nu, \eta)=\mathbb{E}\left[X_{T}^{B, \nu, \eta}+\left(S_{T}^{\nu}-\phi Q_{T}^{B, \nu, \eta}\right)^{\top} Q_{T}^{B, \nu, \eta}-\int_{0}^{T}\left(Q_{t}^{B, \nu, \eta}\right)^{\top} r^{B} Q_{t}^{B, \nu, \eta} \mathrm{~d} t\right]
$$

# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

where $\psi, r^{I}, \phi, r^{B}$ are $K \times K$ positive semi-definite matrices representing inventory control constants. We assume $\phi-\frac{1}{2} h$ is positive semi-definite. The second term in each expression above represents the value of terminal shares marked-to-market at the observed impacted price together with a terminal penalty that is quadratic in inventory. When $\psi(\phi)$ tends to infinity, the informed (broker) trader is incentivized to liquidate their position fully by the end of the period.

In the sequel, we sometimes omit a control in the superscript of a process when we do not need to emphasize its dependence on the control and there is no ambiguity in the context.

In the next lemma, we verify the criteria are well-defined and rewrite them in terms of running costs.
Lemma 2.2. $J^{I}$ defined as (2.9) and $J^{B}$ defined as (2.10) are (real-valued) functionals on $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2} \times \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$. Moreover, they can be written as

$$
J^{I}(\nu, \eta)=\mathbb{E}\left[x^{I}+\left(S_{0}-\psi q^{I}\right)^{\top} q^{I}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left\{-\eta_{t}^{\top} b \eta_{t}+\left(\alpha_{t}+h \nu_{t}-p Y_{t}-2 \psi \eta_{t}-r^{I} Q_{t}^{I}\right)^{\top} Q_{t}^{I}\right\} \mathrm{d} t\right]
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
J^{B}(\nu, \eta)= & \mathbb{E}\left[x^{B}+\left(S_{0}-\phi q^{B}\right)^{\top} q^{B}\right] \\
& +\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left\{-\nu_{t}^{\top} a \nu_{t}+\eta_{t}^{\top} b \eta_{t}+\left(\alpha_{t}+(h-2 \phi) \nu_{t}-p Y_{t}+2 \phi \eta_{t}-r^{B} Q_{t}^{B}\right)^{\top} Q_{t}^{B}\right\} \mathrm{d} t\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. Take $(\nu, \eta) \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2} \times \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$. By Lemma 2.1, Itô's formula implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
& X_{T}^{B}+\left(S_{T}-\phi Q_{T}^{B}\right)^{\top} Q_{T}^{B} \\
& =x^{B}+\left(S_{0}-\phi q^{B}\right)^{\top} q^{B}+\int_{0}^{T} \mathrm{~d} X_{t}^{B}+\sum_{i=1}^{K} \int_{0}^{T}\left(S_{t}^{(i)}-2 \sum_{j=1}^{K} \phi_{i, j} Q_{t}^{B,(j)}\right) \mathrm{d} Q_{t}^{B,(i)}+\sum_{i=1}^{K} \int_{0}^{T} Q_{t}^{B,(i)} \mathrm{d} S_{t}^{(i)} \\
& =x^{B}+\left(S_{0}-\phi q^{B}\right)^{\top} q^{B}+\int_{0}^{T}\left(-\left(S_{t}+a \nu_{t}\right)^{\top} \nu_{t}+\left(S_{t}+b \eta_{t}\right)^{\top} \eta_{t}\right) \mathrm{d} t \\
& \quad+\int_{0}^{T} \sum_{i=1}^{K}\left[\left(S_{t}^{(i)}-2 \sum_{j=1}^{K} \phi_{i, j} Q_{t}^{B,(j)}\right)\left(\nu_{t}^{(i)}-\eta_{t}^{(i)}\right)+Q_{t}^{B,(i)}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{K}\left(h_{i, j} \nu_{t}^{(j)}-p_{i, j} Y_{t}^{(j)}\right)+\alpha_{t}^{(i)}\right)\right] \mathrm{d} t \\
& \quad+\sum_{i=1}^{K} \int_{0}^{T} Q_{t}^{B,(i)} \sum_{j=1}^{K} \sigma_{t}^{(i, j)} \mathrm{d} W_{t}^{(j)} \\
& =x^{B}+\left(S_{0}-\phi q^{B}\right)^{\top} q^{B}+\int_{0}^{T}\left\{-\nu_{t}^{\top} a \nu_{t}+\eta_{t}^{\top} b \eta_{t}+\left(\alpha_{t}+h \nu_{t}-p Y_{t}-2 \phi\left(\nu_{t}-\eta_{t}\right)\right)^{\top} Q_{t}^{B}\right\} \mathrm{d} t \\
& \quad+\sum_{i, j=1}^{K} \int_{0}^{T} Q_{t}^{B,(i)} \sigma_{t}^{(i, j)} \mathrm{d} W_{t}^{(j)}
\end{aligned}
$$

and similarly,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& X_{T}^{I}+\left(S_{T}-\psi Q_{T}^{I}\right)^{\top} Q_{T}^{I} \\
& =x^{I}+\left(S_{0}-\psi q^{I}\right)^{\top} q^{I}+\int_{0}^{T}\left\{-\eta_{t}^{\top} b \eta_{t}+\left(\alpha_{t}+h \nu_{t}-p Y_{t}-2 \psi \eta_{t}\right)^{\top} Q_{t}^{I}\right\} \mathrm{d} t+\sum_{i, j=1}^{K} \int_{0}^{T} Q_{t}^{I,(i)} \sigma_{t}^{(i, j)} \mathrm{d} W_{t}^{(j)}
\end{aligned}
$$

By assumption (2.2) and as $\left\|Q^{B}\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}<\infty$, we have that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|Q_{t}^{B,(i)} \sigma_{t}^{(i, j)}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} t\right] \leq L^{2}\left\|Q^{B}\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2}<\infty
$$

# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

therefore, $\left(\int_{0}^{t} Q_{s}^{B,(i)} \sigma_{s}^{(i, j)} \mathrm{d} W_{s}^{(j)}\right)_{t \in[0, T]}$ is an $\mathbb{F}$-martingale, and hence $\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} Q_{s}^{B,(i)} \sigma_{s}^{(i, j)} \mathrm{d} W_{s}^{(j)}\right]=0$. Similarly, $\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} Q_{s}^{I,(i)} \sigma_{s}^{(i, j)} \mathrm{d} W_{s}^{(j)}\right]=0$. Moreover, since $\nu, \eta, \alpha, Y$ are all in $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|-\nu_{t}^{\top} a \nu_{t}+\eta_{t}^{\top} b \eta_{t}+\left(\alpha_{t}+h \nu_{t}-p Y_{t}-2 \phi\left(\nu_{t}-\eta_{t}\right)\right)^{\top} Q_{t}^{B}\right| \mathrm{d} t\right] \\
& \leq \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left(\|a\| \| \nu_{t} \|^{2}+\|b\|\left|\eta_{t}\right|^{2}+\left(\left|\alpha_{t}\right|+\|h\|\left|\nu_{t}\right|+\|p\|\left|Y_{t}\right|+2 \|\phi\|\left|\nu_{t}-\eta_{t}\right|\right)\left|Q_{t}^{B}\right|\right) \mathrm{d} t\right] \\
& \leq\|a\|\|\nu\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2}+\|b\|\|\eta\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2}+\left(\|\alpha\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}+\|h\|\|\nu\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}+\|p\|\|Y\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}+2\|\phi\|\left\|\nu-\eta\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}\right)\left\|Q^{B}\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}<\infty
\end{aligned}
$$

We also have that

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left(Q_{t}^{B}\right)^{\top} r^{B} Q_{t}^{B} \mathrm{~d} t\right] \leq\left\|r^{B}\right\|\left\|Q^{B}\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2}<\infty \\
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|-\eta_{t}^{\top} b \eta_{t}+\left(\alpha_{t}+h \nu_{t}-p Y_{t}-2 \psi \eta_{t}\right)^{\top} Q_{t}^{I}\right| \mathrm{d} t\right] \\
\leq\|b\|\|\eta\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2}+\left(\|\alpha\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}+\|h\|\|\nu\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}+\|p\|\|Y\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}+2\|\psi\|\left\|\eta\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}\right)\left\|Q^{I}\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}<\infty \\
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left(Q_{t}^{I}\right)^{\top} r^{I} Q_{t}^{I} \mathrm{~d} t\right] \leq\left\|r^{I}\right\|\left\|Q^{I}\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2}<\infty \\
\mathbb{E}\left[\left|x^{B}+\left(S_{0}-\phi q^{B}\right)^{\top} q^{B}\right|\right] \leq \mathbb{E}\left[\left|x^{B}\right|\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\left|S_{0}\right|^{2}\right]^{1 / 2} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|q^{B}\right|^{2}\right]^{1 / 2}+\|\phi\| \mathbb{E}\left[\left|q^{B}\right|^{2}\right]<\infty
\end{gathered}
$$

and

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left|x^{I}+\left(S_{0}-\psi q^{I}\right)^{\top} q^{I}\right|\right] \leq \mathbb{E}\left[\left|x^{I}\right|\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\left|S_{0}\right|^{2}\right]^{1 / 2} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|q^{I}\right|^{2}\right]^{1 / 2}+\|\psi\| \mathbb{E}\left[\left|q^{I}\right|^{2}\right]<\infty
$$

Therefore,

$$
J^{I}(\nu, \eta)=\mathbb{E}\left[x^{I}+\left(S_{0}-\psi q^{I}\right)^{\top} q^{I}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left\{-\eta_{t}^{\top} b \eta_{t}+\left(\alpha_{t}+h \nu_{t}-p Y_{t}-2 \psi \eta_{t}-r^{I} Q_{t}^{I}\right)^{\top} Q_{t}^{I}\right\} \mathrm{d} t\right] \in \mathbb{R}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
J^{B}(\nu, \eta)= & \mathbb{E}\left[x^{B}+\left(S_{0}-\phi q^{B}\right)^{\top} q^{B}\right] \\
& +\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left\{-\nu_{t}^{\top} a \nu_{t}+\eta_{t}^{\top} b \eta_{t}+\left(\alpha_{t}+(h-2 \phi) \nu_{t}-p Y_{t}+2 \phi \eta_{t}-r^{B} Q_{t}^{B}\right)^{\top} Q_{t}^{B}\right\} \mathrm{d} t\right] \in \mathbb{R}
\end{aligned}
$$

We end this section by defining the notion of Nash equilibrium between the broker and the informed trader.
Definition 2.3. A pair $(\nu, \eta) \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2} \times \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$ is a Nash equilibrium between the broker and the informed trader if $\nu$ is a maximizer of $J^{B}(\cdot, \eta)$ over $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$ and $\eta$ is a maximizer of $J^{I}(\nu, \cdot)$ over $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$.

## 3 Convex analysis of the performance criteria

In this section, we study the convexity and differentiability of the borker's and informed trader's criteria. Specifically, we show $J^{I}$ and $J^{B}$ are strictly concave and Găuteaux-differentiable in the component over which the corresponding agent maximizes. We then characterize the maximizers in terms of the Găuteaux derivatives.

First, we obtain the concavity of the informed trader's criterion.

# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

Proposition 3.1. For $\nu \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$, the functional $J^{I}(\nu, \cdot): \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is concave.
Proof. Fix $\nu \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$ and $\eta, \kappa \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$. Let $\rho \in(0,1)$. First, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
Q_{t}^{I, \rho \eta+(1-\rho) \kappa}=q^{I}+\int_{0}^{t}\left(\left(\rho \eta_{s}+(1-\rho) \kappa_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right. & =\rho\left(q^{I}+\int_{0}^{t} \eta_{s} \mathrm{~d} s\right)+(1-\rho)\left(q^{I}+\int_{0}^{t} \kappa_{s} \mathrm{~d} s\right) \\
& =\rho Q_{t}^{I, \eta}+(1-\rho) Q_{t}^{I, \kappa}
\end{aligned}
$$

Next, by lemma 2.2,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& J^{I}(\nu, \rho \eta+(1-\rho) \kappa) \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[x^{I}+\left(S_{0}-\psi q^{I}\right)^{\top} q^{I}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left\{\left(\alpha_{t}+h \nu_{t}-p Y_{t}\right)^{\top}\left(\rho Q_{t}^{I, \eta}+(1-\rho) Q_{t}^{I, \kappa}\right)\right\} \mathrm{d} t\right] \\
& \quad+\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left\{-\left(\rho \eta_{t}+(1-\rho) \kappa_{t}\right)^{\top} b\left(\rho \eta_{t}+(1-\rho) \kappa_{t}\right)\right\} \mathrm{d} t\right] \\
& \quad+\rho \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left(-2 \psi \eta_{t}-r^{I} Q_{t}^{I, \eta}\right)^{\top}\left(\rho Q_{t}^{I, \eta}+(1-\rho) Q_{t}^{I, \kappa}\right) \mathrm{d} t\right] \\
& \quad+(1-\rho) \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left(-2 \psi \kappa_{t}-r^{I} Q_{t}^{I, \kappa}\right)^{\top}\left(\rho Q_{t}^{I, \eta}+(1-\rho) Q_{t}^{I, \kappa}\right) \mathrm{d} t\right] \\
& =\rho J^{I}(\nu, \eta)+(1-\rho) J^{I}(\nu, \kappa) \\
& \quad+\rho(1-\rho) \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left\{\eta_{t}^{\top} b \eta_{t}+\kappa_{t}^{\top} b \kappa_{t}-\eta_{t}^{\top} b \kappa_{t}-\kappa_{t}^{\top} b \eta_{t}\right\} \mathrm{d} t\right] \\
& \quad+\rho(1-\rho) \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left(-2 \psi \eta_{t}-r^{I} Q_{t}^{I, \eta}\right)^{\top}\left(-Q_{t}^{I, \eta}+Q_{t}^{I, \kappa}\right) \mathrm{d} t\right] \\
& \quad+\rho(1-\rho) \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left(-2 \psi \kappa_{t}-r^{I} Q_{t}^{I, \kappa}\right)^{\top}\left(Q_{t}^{I, \eta}-Q_{t}^{I, \kappa}\right) \mathrm{d} t\right] \\
& =\rho J^{I}(\nu, \eta)+(1-\rho) J^{I}(\nu, \kappa)+\rho(1-\rho) \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left(\eta_{t}-\kappa_{t}\right)^{\top} b\left(\eta_{t}-\kappa_{t}\right) \mathrm{d} t\right] \\
& \quad+2 \rho(1-\rho) \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left(\eta_{t}-\kappa_{t}\right)^{\top} \psi\left(Q_{t}^{I, \eta}-Q_{t}^{I, \kappa}\right) \mathrm{d} t\right] \\
& \quad+\rho(1-\rho) \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left(Q_{t}^{I, \eta}-Q_{t}^{I, \kappa}\right)^{\top} r^{I}\left(Q_{t}^{I, \eta}-Q_{t}^{I, \kappa}\right) \mathrm{d} t\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Notice

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left(\eta_{t}-\kappa_{t}\right)^{\top} \psi\left(Q_{t}^{I, \eta}-Q_{t}^{I, \kappa}\right) \mathrm{d} t\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \int_{0}^{t}\left(\eta_{t}-\kappa_{t}\right)^{\top} \psi\left(\eta_{s}-\kappa_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mathrm{~d} t\right]
$$

Further, as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \int_{0}^{t}\left|\left(\eta_{t}-\kappa_{t}\right)^{\top} \psi\left(\eta_{s}-\kappa_{s}\right)\right| \mathrm{d} s \mathrm{~d} t\right] & \leq\|\psi\| \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \int_{0}^{t}\left|\eta_{s}-\kappa_{s}\right|\left|\eta_{t}-\kappa_{t}\right| \mathrm{d} s \mathrm{~d} t\right] \\
& \leq\|\psi\| \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\int_{0}^{T}\left|\eta_{t}-\kappa_{t}\right| \mathrm{d} t\right)^{2}\right] \\
& \leq T\|\psi\| \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|\eta_{t}-\kappa_{t}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} t\right]=T\|\psi\|\|\eta-\kappa\|_{R^{2}}^{2}<\infty
\end{aligned}
$$

# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

Fubini's theorem implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \int_{0}^{t}\left(\eta_{t}-\kappa_{t}\right)^{\top} \psi\left(\eta_{s}-\kappa_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mathrm{~d} t\right] & =\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \int_{s}^{T}\left(\eta_{t}-\kappa_{t}\right)^{\top} \psi\left(\eta_{s}-\kappa_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} t \mathrm{~d} s\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \int_{t}^{T}\left(\eta_{s}-\kappa_{s}\right)^{\top} \psi\left(\eta_{t}-\kappa_{t}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mathrm{~d} t\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \int_{t}^{T}\left(\left(\eta_{s}-\kappa_{s}\right)^{\top} \psi\left(\eta_{t}-\kappa_{t}\right)\right)^{\top} \mathrm{d} s \mathrm{~d} t\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \int_{t}^{T}\left(\eta_{t}-\kappa_{t}\right)^{\top} \psi\left(\eta_{s}-\kappa_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mathrm{~d} t\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Combining this with (3.2) gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left(\eta_{t}-\kappa_{t}\right)^{\top} \psi\left(Q_{t}^{I, \eta}-Q_{t}^{I, \kappa}\right) \mathrm{d} t\right] & =\frac{1}{2} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \int_{0}^{T}\left(\eta_{t}-\kappa_{t}\right)^{\top} \psi\left(\eta_{s}-\kappa_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mathrm{~d} t\right] \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(Q_{T}^{I, \eta}-Q_{T}^{I, \kappa}\right)^{\top} \psi\left(Q_{T}^{I, \eta}-Q_{T}^{I, \kappa}\right)\right] \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

due to the positive semi-definiteness of $\psi$. As $r^{I}$ and $b$ are positive semi-definite, we have

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left(Q_{t}^{I, \eta}-Q_{t}^{I, \kappa}\right)^{\top} r^{I}\left(Q_{t}^{I, \eta}-Q_{t}^{I, \kappa}\right) \mathrm{d} t\right] \geq 0
$$

and

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left(\eta_{t}-\kappa_{t}\right)^{\top} b\left(\eta_{t}-\kappa_{t}\right) \mathrm{d} t\right] \geq 0
$$

Combining (3.1), (3.3), (3.4), and (3.5) gives

$$
J^{I}(\nu, \rho \eta+(1-\rho) \kappa) \geq \rho J^{I}(\nu, \eta)+(1-\rho) J^{I}(\nu, \kappa)
$$

Second, we obtain concavity of the broker's criterion. Note that, unlike in [9], we obtain the following result without any further restriction on $a, p, h$, and $T$.

& =\rho Y_{t}^{\nu}+(1-\rho) Y_{t}^{\zeta}
\end{aligned}
$$

\end{aligned}
$$

Combining this and (3.7) gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left(\nu_{t}-\zeta_{t}\right)^{\top}(2 \phi-h)\left(Q_{t}^{B, \nu}-Q_{t}^{B, \zeta}\right) \mathrm{d} t\right] & =\frac{1}{2} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \int_{0}^{T}\left(\nu_{t}-\zeta_{t}\right)^{\top}(2 \phi-h)\left(\nu_{s}-\zeta_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mathrm{~d} t\right] \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(Q_{T}^{B, \nu}-Q_{T}^{B, \zeta}\right)^{\top}(2 \phi-h)\left(Q_{T}^{B, \nu}-Q_{T}^{B, \zeta}\right)\right] \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

due to the positive semi-definiteness of $2 \phi-h$. Since $r^{B}$ and $a$ are positive semi-definite, we have

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left(Q_{t}^{B, \nu}-Q_{t}^{B, \zeta}\right)^{\top} r^{B}\left(Q_{t}^{B, \nu}-Q_{t}^{B, \zeta}\right) \mathrm{d} t\right] \geq 0
$$

and

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left(\nu_{t}-\zeta_{t}\right)^{\top} a\left(\nu_{t}-\zeta_{t}\right) \mathrm{d} t\right] \geq 0
$$

The dynamics of $Y$ and $Q^{B}$ implies

$$
Y_{t}^{\nu}-Y_{t}^{\zeta}=h \int_{0}^{t}\left(\nu_{s}-\zeta_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s-p \int_{0}^{t}\left(Y_{s}^{\nu}-Y_{s}^{\zeta}\right) \mathrm{d} s=h\left(Q_{t}^{B, \nu}-Q_{t}^{B, \zeta}\right)-p \int_{0}^{t}\left(Y_{s}^{\nu}-Y_{s}^{\zeta}\right) \mathrm{d} s
$$

Since $p$ and $h$ commute, $\mathrm{e}^{u p}$ and $h$ commute as well, thus from (2.3) we see that

$$
Y_{t}^{\nu}-Y_{t}^{\zeta}=h \int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{e}^{(s-t) p}\left(\nu_{s}-\zeta_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s
$$

Let $h^{\dagger}$ be the pseudoinverse of $h$. Since $p$ and $h$ are positive semi-definite and commute, they are simultaneously diagonalizable (see, for example, Theorem 5.76 of [4]), that is, there is an invertible $K \times K$ matrix $O$ such that $p=O \hat{p} O^{-1}$ and $h=O \hat{h} O^{-1}$, where $\hat{p}$ and $\hat{h}$ are diagonal matrices whose diagonals consist of eigenvalues of $p$ and $h$, which are nonnegative, respectively. Then $h^{\dagger}=O \hat{h}^{\dagger} O^{-1}$, where $\hat{h}^{\dagger}$ is the diagonal matrix obtained by replacing each nonzero entry of $\hat{h}$ with its reciprocal. Thus $h^{\dagger}$ is positive semi-definite. Since $p h^{\dagger}=O \hat{p} O^{-1} O \hat{h}^{\dagger} O^{-1}=O \hat{p} \hat{h}^{\dagger} O^{-1}$, $p h^{\dagger}$ is positive semi-definite. It follows from (3.11) that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{0}^{T}\left(Y_{t}^{\nu}-Y_{t}^{\zeta}\right)^{\top} p\left(Q_{t}^{B, \nu}-Q_{t}^{B, \zeta}\right) \mathrm{d} t \\
& =\int_{0}^{T}\left(\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{e}^{(s-t) p}\left(\nu_{s}-\zeta_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right)^{\top} h p\left(Q_{t}^{B, \nu}-Q_{t}^{B, \zeta}\right) \mathrm{d} t \\
& =\int_{0}^{T}\left(\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{e}^{(s-t) p}\left(\nu_{s}-\zeta_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right)^{\top} p h\left(Q_{t}^{B, \nu}-Q_{t}^{B, \zeta}\right) \mathrm{d} t \\
& =\int_{0}^{T}\left(\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{e}^{(s-t) p}\left(\nu_{s}-\zeta_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right)^{\top} p h h^{\dagger} h\left(Q_{t}^{B, \nu}-Q_{t}^{B, \zeta}\right) \mathrm{d} t \\
& =\int_{0}^{T}\left(\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{e}^{(s-t) p}\left(\nu_{s}-\zeta_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right)^{\top} p h h^{\dagger}\left(Y_{t}^{\nu}-Y_{t}^{\zeta}+p \int_{0}^{t}\left(Y_{s}^{\nu}-Y_{s}^{\zeta}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right) \mathrm{d} t \\
& =\int_{0}^{T}\left(\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{e}^{(s-t) p}\left(\nu_{s}-\zeta_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right)^{\top} h p h^{\dagger}\left(Y_{t}^{\nu}-Y_{t}^{\zeta}+p \int_{0}^{t}\left(Y_{s}^{\nu}-Y_{s}^{\zeta}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right) \mathrm{d} t \\
& =\int_{0}^{T}\left(Y_{t}^{\nu}-Y_{t}^{\zeta}\right)^{\top} p h^{\dagger}\left(Y_{t}^{\nu}-Y_{t}^{\zeta}+p \int_{0}^{t}\left(Y_{s}^{\nu}-Y_{s}^{\zeta}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right) \mathrm{d} t
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\int_{0}^{T}\left(Y_{t}^{\nu}-Y_{t}^{\zeta}\right)^{\top} p h^{\dagger}\left(Y_{t}^{\nu}-Y_{t}^{\zeta}\right) \mathrm{d} t+\int_{0}^{T}\left(Y_{t}^{\nu}-Y_{t}^{\zeta}\right)^{\top} p h^{\dagger} p \int_{0}^{t}\left(Y_{s}^{\nu}-Y_{s}^{\zeta}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mathrm{~d} t \\
& =\int_{0}^{T}\left(Y_{t}^{\nu}-Y_{t}^{\zeta}\right)^{\top} p h^{\dagger}\left(Y_{t}^{\nu}-Y_{t}^{\zeta}\right) \mathrm{d} t+\frac{1}{2}\left(p \int_{0}^{T}\left(Y_{t}^{\nu}-Y_{t}^{\zeta}\right) \mathrm{d} t\right)^{\top} h^{\dagger} p \int_{0}^{T}\left(Y_{t}^{\nu}-Y_{t}^{\zeta}\right) \mathrm{d} t \geq 0

$$
J^{B}(\rho \nu+(1-\rho) \zeta, \eta) \geq \rho J^{B}(\nu, \eta)+(1-\rho) J^{B}(\zeta, \eta)
$$

Next, we provide some important results regarding Gâteaux-differentiability and maximizing concave functions. For a real vector space $V$ and a functional $f$ on $V$, we say $f$ is Gâteaux-differentiable at $v \in V$ if there exists a linear functional $v^{*}$ on $V$ such that the canonical pairing

$$
\left\langle v^{*}, u\right\rangle=\lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{f(v+\varepsilon u)-f(v)}{\varepsilon}
$$

for all $u \in V$, in which case $v^{*}$ is called the Gâteaux-derivative of $f$ at $v$ and is denoted by $\mathcal{D} f(v)$.
Lemma 3.3. Let $V$ be a vector space and $f$ be a concave functional on $V$. Suppose $f$ is Gâteaux-differentiable at $v \in V$. Then $f$ has a maximum at $v$ if and only if $\mathcal{D} f(v)=0$.

Proof. Suppose $f$ has a maximum at $v$. Let $u \in V$. For $\varepsilon>0$,

$$
\frac{f(v+\varepsilon u)-f(v)}{\varepsilon} \leq 0
$$

and

$$
\frac{f(v-\varepsilon u)-f(v)}{\varepsilon} \leq 0
$$

Hence

$$
\langle\mathcal{D} f(v), u\rangle=\lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{f(v+\varepsilon u)-f(v)}{\varepsilon} \leq 0
$$

and

$$
-\langle\mathcal{D} f(v), u\rangle=\langle\mathcal{D} f(v),-u\rangle=\lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{f(v-\varepsilon u)-f(v)}{\varepsilon} \leq 0
$$

where the linearity of $\mathcal{D} f(v)$ is used in the second calculation. This means $\langle\mathcal{D} f(v), u\rangle=0$. Hence $\mathcal{D} f(v)=0$.
Conversely, suppose $\mathcal{D} f(v)=0$. Let $u \in V$. For $\varepsilon \in(0,1)$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(v) & =f(u)-\frac{\varepsilon f(u)-\varepsilon f(v)}{\varepsilon} \\
& =f(u)-\frac{\varepsilon f(u)+(1-\varepsilon) f(v)-f(v)}{\varepsilon} \\
& \geq f(u)-\frac{f(\varepsilon u+(1-\varepsilon) v)-f(v)}{\varepsilon}=f(u)-\frac{f(v+\varepsilon(u-v))-f(v)}{\varepsilon}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the concavity of $f$ is used for the inequality. Taking $\varepsilon \rightarrow 0^{+}$gives $f(v) \geq f(u)-\langle\mathcal{D} f(v), u-v\rangle=f(u)$. Hence $f$ has a maximum at $v$.

The next two propositions pertain to the Gâteaux-differentiability of the informed trader's and the broker's performance criteria.
Proposition 3.4. For $\nu \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{Q}}^{2}, J^{I}(\nu, \cdot): \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is Gâteaux-differentiable at every $\eta \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$ with Gâteaux-derivative given by

$$
\left.\left\langle\mathcal{D} J^{I}(\nu, \cdot)\right|_{\eta}, \kappa\right\rangle=\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \kappa_{t}^{\top}\left(-2 b \eta_{t}-2 \psi Q_{t}^{I, \eta}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 \psi \eta_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I, \eta}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right) \mathrm{d} t\right]
$$

for all $\kappa \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$.

Proof. Fix $\nu \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$ and $\eta, \kappa \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{P}}^{2}$. For $\varepsilon>0$,

$$
Q_{t}^{I, \eta+\varepsilon \kappa}=q^{I}+\int_{0}^{t}\left(\eta_{s}+\varepsilon \kappa_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s=q^{I}+\int_{0}^{t} \eta_{s} \mathrm{~d} s+\varepsilon \int_{0}^{t} \kappa_{s} \mathrm{~d} s=Q_{t}^{I, \eta}+\varepsilon \int_{0}^{t} \kappa_{s} \mathrm{~d} s
$$

so

$$
\begin{aligned}
& J^{I}(\nu, \eta+\varepsilon \kappa)-J^{I}(\nu, \eta) \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left\{-\left(\eta_{t}+\varepsilon \kappa_{t}\right)^{\top} b\left(\eta_{t}+\varepsilon \kappa_{t}\right)+\eta_{t}^{\top} b \eta_{t}+\left(\alpha_{t}+h \nu_{t}-p Y_{t}\right)^{\top}\left(\varepsilon \int_{0}^{t} \kappa_{s} \mathrm{~d} s\right)\right\} \mathrm{d} t\right] \\
& \quad+\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}-2\left\{\left(\eta_{t}+\varepsilon \kappa_{t}\right)^{\top} \psi\left(Q_{t}^{I, \eta}+\varepsilon \int_{0}^{t} \kappa_{s} \mathrm{~d} s\right)-\eta_{t}^{\top} \psi Q_{t}^{I, \eta}\right\} \mathrm{d} t\right] \\
& \quad+\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}-\left\{\left(Q_{t}^{I, \eta}+\varepsilon \int_{0}^{t} \kappa_{s} \mathrm{~d} s\right)^{\top} r^{I}\left(Q_{t}^{I, \eta}+\varepsilon \int_{0}^{t} \kappa_{s} \mathrm{~d} s\right)-\left(Q_{t}^{I, \eta}\right)^{\top} r^{I} Q_{t}^{I, \eta}\right\} \mathrm{d} t\right] \\
& =\varepsilon \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \kappa_{t}^{\top}\left(-2 b \eta_{t}-2 \psi Q_{t}^{I, \eta}\right) \mathrm{d} t+\int_{0}^{T} \int_{0}^{t} \kappa_{s}^{\top}\left(\alpha_{t}+h \nu_{t}-p Y_{t}-2 \psi \eta_{t}-2 r^{I} Q_{t}^{I, \eta}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mathrm{~d} t\right] \\
& \quad-\varepsilon^{2} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left\{\kappa_{t}^{\top} b \kappa_{t}+2 \kappa_{t}^{\top} \psi \int_{0}^{t} \kappa_{s} \mathrm{~d} s+\left(\int_{0}^{t} \kappa_{s} \mathrm{~d} s\right)^{\top} r^{I} \int_{0}^{t} \kappa_{s} \mathrm{~d} s\right\}\right] \\
& =\varepsilon \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \kappa_{t}^{\top}\left(-2 b \eta_{t}-2 \psi Q_{t}^{I, \eta}\right) \mathrm{d} t+\int_{0}^{T} \int_{t}^{T} \kappa_{t}^{\top}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 \psi \eta_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I, \eta}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mathrm{~d} t\right] \\
& \quad-\varepsilon^{2} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left\{\kappa_{t}^{\top} b \kappa_{t}+2 \kappa_{t}^{\top} \psi \int_{0}^{t} \kappa_{s} \mathrm{~d} s+\left(\int_{0}^{t} \kappa_{s} \mathrm{~d} s\right)^{\top} r^{I} \int_{0}^{t} \kappa_{s} \mathrm{~d} s\right\}\right] \\
& =\varepsilon^{2} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \kappa_{t}^{\top}\left\{-2 b \eta_{t}-2 \psi Q_{t}^{I, \eta}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 \psi \eta_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I, \eta}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right\} \mathrm{d} t\right] \\
& \quad-\varepsilon^{2} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left\{\kappa_{t}^{\top} b \kappa_{t}+2 \kappa_{t}^{\top} \psi \int_{0}^{t} \kappa_{s} \mathrm{~d} s+\left(\int_{0}^{t} \kappa_{s} \mathrm{~d} s\right)^{\top} r^{I} \int_{0}^{t} \kappa_{s} \mathrm{~d} s\right\}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle\mathcal{D} J^{I}(\nu, \cdot)\right|_{\eta}, \kappa\rangle & =\lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{J^{I}(\nu, \eta+\varepsilon \kappa)-J^{I}(\nu, \eta)}{\varepsilon} \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \kappa_{t}^{\top}\left\{-2 b \eta_{t}-2 \psi Q_{t}^{I, \eta}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 \psi \eta_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I, \eta}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right\} \mathrm{d} t\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

The map $\kappa \mapsto\left\langle\mathcal{D} J^{I}(\nu, \cdot)\right|_{\eta}, \kappa\rangle$ is clearly linear.
