# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

Next, we characterize the maximizers of $J^{I}(\nu, \cdot)$ and $J^{B}(\cdot, \eta)$ using the concavity and Gâteaux-differentiability we just proved. Due the partial information that the broker works in, this involves estimating processes using some filtration. We have to ensure all filtered processes that arise are admissible, which requires them to be progressively measurable. This is achieved through Lemma 3.7. We first state a well-known result.
Theorem 3.6. Let $(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mathbb{P})$ be a complete measure space on which a filtration $\mathbb{Y}=\left(\mathcal{Y}_{t}\right)$ satisfying the usual conditions is defined. Then every $\mathbb{Y}$-martingale has a càd-làg modification.

Proof. See Theorem 3.13 in Chapter 1 of [21].
In the remainder of this article, we assume all martingales adapted to a filtration satisfying usual conditions have càd-làg sample paths.
Lemma 3.7. Let $(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mathbb{P})$ be a complete measure space on which a filtration $\mathbb{Y}=\left(\mathcal{Y}_{t}\right)_{t \in[0, T]}$ satisfying the usual conditions is defined. Then for each $\mathbb{R}^{K}$-valued jointly measurable process $\xi$ such that $\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|\xi_{t}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} t\right]<\infty$, there is a unique $\hat{\xi} \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{Y}}^{s}$ such that $\hat{\xi}_{t}=\mathbb{E}\left[\xi_{t} \mid \mathcal{Y}_{t}\right]$ a.s. for a.e. $t \in[0, T]$. We call $\hat{\xi}$ the projection of $\xi$ onto $\mathbb{Y}$.

Proof. To see uniqueness, suppose both $\hat{\xi}$ and $\hat{\xi}$ satisfy the desired properties. Then $\hat{\xi}_{t}-\hat{\xi}_{t}=0$ a.s. for a.e. $t \in[0, T]$, therefore

$$
\|\hat{\xi}-\hat{\xi}\|_{D^{3}}^{2}=\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|\hat{\xi}_{t}-\hat{\xi}_{t}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} t\right]=\int_{0}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|\hat{\xi}_{t}-\hat{\xi}_{t}\right|^{2}\right] \mathrm{d} t=0
$$

To see existence, first assume $\xi$ is an elementary processes such that

$$
\xi_{t}(\omega)=\sum_{i=1}^{p-1} \xi^{(i)}(\omega) \mathbf{1}_{\left(t_{i}, t_{i+1}\right]}(t)
$$

where $0=t_{0}<t_{1}<\cdots<t_{p}=T$, and $\xi^{(i)}$ are bounded $\mathcal{F}$-measurable random variables. For each $i$, consider the $\left(\mathcal{Y}_{t}\right)_{t \in\left[t_{i}, t_{i+1}\right]}$-martingale $\left(\hat{\xi}_{t}^{(i)}\right)_{t \in\left[t_{i}, t_{i+1}\right]}$ defined by $\hat{\xi}_{t}^{(i)}=\mathbb{E}\left[\xi^{(i)} \mid \mathcal{Y}_{t}\right]$, which can be chosen to have càd-làg paths by Theorem 3.6 because $\mathbb{Y}$ satisfies the usual conditions. By further setting $\hat{\xi}_{t}^{(i)}=0$ for $t \in\left[0, t_{i}\right)$ and $\hat{\xi}_{t}^{(i)}=\hat{\xi}_{t+1}^{(i)}$ for $t \in\left(t_{i+1}, T\right]$, we obtain a $\mathbb{Y}$-adapted càd-làg process $\left(\hat{\xi}_{t}^{(i)}\right)_{t \in[0, T]}$, which is $\mathbb{Y}$-progressively measurable. Define the process $\left(\hat{\xi}_{t}\right)_{t \in[0, T]}$ by

$$
\hat{\xi}_{t}(\omega)=\sum_{i=1}^{p-1} \hat{\xi}_{t}^{(i)}(\omega) \mathbf{1}_{\left(t_{i}, t_{i+1}\right]}(t)
$$

Then $\hat{\xi}$ is a $\mathbb{Y}$-progressively measurable process as a sum of products of $\mathbb{Y}$-progressively measurable processes. By construction, $\hat{\xi}_{t}=\mathbb{E}\left[\xi_{t} \mid \mathcal{Y}_{t}\right]$ a.s. for all $t \in[0, T]$.

Next, let $\xi$ be an arbitrary jointly measurable process s.t. $\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|\xi_{t}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} t\right]<\infty$. By considering $\xi$ as an adapted process with respect to its natural filtration $\mathbb{Y}^{\xi}$, it has a modification $\hat{\xi} \in \mathbb{H}_{\xi \xi}^{2}$. By Proposition 5.3 in [18], there is a sequence $\left(\xi^{[n]}\right)_{n}$ of elementary processes converging to $\hat{\xi}$ in $\mathbb{H}^{2}$. By the argument above, there is a $\mathbb{Y}$-progressively measurable process $\hat{\xi}^{[n]}$ such that $\hat{\xi}_{t}^{[n]}=\mathbb{E}\left[\xi_{t}^{[n]} \mid \mathcal{Y}_{t}\right]$ a.s. for all $t \in[0, T]$ for each $n$. Since

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|\hat{\xi}_{t}^{[n]}-\hat{\xi}_{t}^{[m]}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} t\right] & =\int_{0}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|\mathbb{E}\left[\xi_{t}^{[n]} \mid \mathcal{Y}_{t}\right]-\mathbb{E}\left[\xi_{t}^{[m]} \mid \mathcal{Y}_{t}\right]\right|^{2}\right] \mathrm{d} t \\
& \leq \int_{0}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{E}\left[\left|\xi_{t}^{[n]}-\xi_{t}^{[m]}\right|^{2}\right] \mathcal{Y}_{t}\right]\right] \mathrm{d} t \\
& =\int_{0}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|\xi_{t}^{[n]}-\xi_{t}^{[m]}\right|^{2}\right] \mathrm{d} t
\end{aligned}
$$

# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

$$
=\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|\xi_{t}^{[n]}-\xi_{t}^{[m]}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} t\right]
$$

$\left(\hat{\xi}^{[n]}\right)_{n}$ is Cauchy in $\mathbb{H}^{2}$, thus converging to a process $\hat{\xi} \in \mathbb{H}_{\xi}^{2}$, i.e.,

$$
\lim _{n \rightarrow 0} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|\hat{\xi}_{t}^{[n]}-\hat{\xi}_{t}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} t\right]=\lim _{n \rightarrow 0} \int_{0}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|\hat{\xi}_{t}^{[n]}-\hat{\xi}_{t}\right|^{2}\right] \mathrm{d} t=0
$$

This implies there is a subsequence $\left(n_{k}\right)_{k}$ such that

$$
\lim _{k \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|\hat{\xi}_{t}^{\left[n_{k}\right]}-\hat{\xi}_{t}\right|^{2}\right]=0 \quad \text { for a.e. } t \in[0, T]
$$

Recall that $\left(\xi^{[n]}\right)_{n}$ converges to $\bar{\xi}$ in $\mathbb{H}^{2}$, so there is a further subsequence $\left(n_{k_{j}}\right)_{j}$ such that

$$
\lim _{j \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|\xi_{t}^{\left[n_{k_{j}}\right]}-\bar{\xi}_{t}\right|^{2}\right]=0 \quad \text { for a.e. } t \in[0, T]
$$

It follows that for a.e. $t \in[0, T]$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\left|\hat{\xi}_{t}-\mathbb{E}\left[\bar{\xi}_{t} \mid \mathcal{Y}_{t}\right]\right|^{2}\right]\right)^{1 / 2} & \leq\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\left|\hat{\xi}_{t}-\xi_{t}^{\left[n_{k_{j}}\right]}\right|^{2}\right]\right)^{1 / 2}+\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\left|\xi_{t}^{\left[n_{k_{j}}\right]}-\mathbb{E}\left|\hat{\xi}_{t}\right| \mathcal{Y}_{t}\right]\right|^{2}\right]\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& =\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\left|\hat{\xi}_{t}-\xi_{t}^{\left[n_{k_{j}}\right]}\right|^{2}\right]\right)^{1 / 2}+\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\left|\mathbb{E}\left[\xi_{t}^{\left[n_{k_{j}}\right]}-\bar{\xi}_{t} \mid \mathcal{Y}_{t}\right]\right|^{2}\right]\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& \leq\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\left|\hat{\xi}_{t}-\xi_{t}^{\left[n_{k_{j}}\right]}\right|^{2}\right]\right)^{1 / 2}+\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\left|\xi_{t}^{\left[n_{k_{j}}\right]}-\bar{\xi}_{t}\right|^{2}\right]\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& \xrightarrow{j \rightarrow \infty} 0
\end{aligned}
$$

meaning that $\hat{\xi}_{s}=\mathbb{E}\left[\bar{\xi}_{s} \mid \mathcal{Y}_{s}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\xi_{s} \mid \mathcal{Y}_{s}\right]$ a.s.
The next two propositions provide conditions which separately maximize the informed trader's and the broker's performance criteria with the other agent's strategy held fixed.
Proposition 3.8. Let $\nu \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$. Then $\eta$ maximizes $J^{I}(\nu, \cdot)$ over $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$ if and only if

$$
\eta_{t}=\frac{1}{2} b^{-1} \mathbb{E}\left[-2 \psi Q_{T}^{I, \eta}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I, \eta}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right] \quad \text { a.s. for a.e. } t
$$

Proof. Fix $\nu \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$ and $\eta \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$. By Proposition 3.1, Lemma 3.3, and Proposition 3.4, $\eta$ maximizes $J^{I}(\nu, \cdot)$ over $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$ if and only if

$$
\left\langle\mathcal{D} J^{I}(\nu, \cdot)\right|_{\eta}, \kappa\right\rangle=0, \quad \forall \kappa \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle\mathcal{D} J^{I}(\nu, \cdot)\right|_{\eta}, \kappa\right\rangle & =\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \kappa_{t}^{\top}\left\{-2 b \eta_{t}-2 \psi Q_{t}^{I}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 \psi \eta_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right\} \mathrm{d} t\right] \\
& =\int_{0}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[\kappa_{t}^{\top}\left\{-2 b \eta_{t}-2 \psi Q_{T}^{I}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right\}\right] \mathrm{d} t \\
& =\int_{0}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{E}\left[\kappa_{t}^{\top}\left\{-2 b \eta_{t}-2 \psi Q_{T}^{I}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right\} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right]\right] \mathrm{d} t \\
& =\int_{0}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[\kappa_{t}^{\top}\left\{-2 b \eta_{t}+\mathbb{E}\left[-2 \psi Q_{T}^{I}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right]\right\}\right] \mathrm{d} t
\end{aligned}
$$

# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

Assume (3.14) holds. In particular, by Proposition 3.7 we can choose $\kappa \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$ to be the process $\kappa_{t}=-2 b \eta_{t}+\kappa_{t}^{\prime}$, where $\kappa^{\prime}$ is the process in $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$ such that

$$
\kappa_{t}^{\prime}=\mathbb{E}\left[-2 \psi Q_{T}^{I}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right] \quad \text { a.s. for a.e. } t
$$

Hence for a.e. $t$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left[\kappa_{t}^{\top}\left\{-2 b \eta_{t}+\mathbb{E}\left[-2 \psi Q_{T}^{I}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right]\right\}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\left|-2 b \eta_{t}+\mathbb{E}\left[-2 \psi Q_{T}^{I}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right]\right|^{2}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Then (3.14) and (3.15) imply

$$
0=\int_{0}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|-2 b \eta_{t}+\mathbb{E}\left[-2 \psi Q_{T}^{I}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right]\right|^{2}\right] \mathrm{d} t
$$

so

$$
-2 b \eta_{t}+\mathbb{E}\left[-2 \psi Q_{T}^{I}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right]=0 \quad \text { a.s. for a.e. } t
$$

(3.13) then follows.

Conversely, (3.13) implies (3.14) due to (3.15).
Proposition 3.9. Let $\eta \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$. Then $\nu$ maximizes $J^{B}(\cdot, \eta)$ over $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$ if and only if

$$
\nu_{t}=\frac{1}{2} a^{-1} \mathbb{E}\left[-(2 \phi-h) Q_{T}^{B}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \eta_{s}-p Y_{s}-\left(h \mathrm{e}^{(t-s) p} p+2 r^{B}\right) Q_{s}^{B}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \quad \text { a.s. for a.e. } t
$$

Proof. Fix $\nu \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$ and $\eta \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$. By Proposition 3.2, Lemma 3.3, and Proposition 3.5, $\nu$ maximizes $J^{B}(\cdot, \eta)$ over $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$ if and only if

$$
\left.\left.\langle\mathcal{D} J^{B}(\cdot, \eta)\right|_{\nu}, \zeta\right\rangle=0, \quad \forall \zeta \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left.\left.\langle\mathcal{D} J^{B}(\cdot, \eta)\right|_{\nu}, \zeta\right\rangle= & \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \zeta_{t}^{\top}\left\{-2 a \nu_{t}-(2 \phi-h) Q_{t}^{B}\right.\right. \\
& \left.\quad+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+2 \phi \eta_{s}-(2 \phi-h) \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-\left(h \mathrm{e}^{(t-s) p} p+2 r^{B}\right) Q_{s}^{B}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right\} \mathrm{d} t\right] \\
= & \int_{0}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[\zeta_{t}^{\top}\left\{-2 a \nu_{t}+\mathbb{E}\left[-(2 \phi-h) Q_{T}^{B}\right.\right.\right. \\
& \left.\left.\quad+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \eta_{s}-p Y_{s}-\left(h \mathrm{e}^{(t-s) p} p+2 r^{B}\right) Q_{s}^{B}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right\}\right\}\right] \mathrm{d} t
\end{aligned}
$$

Assume (3.17) holds. In particular, by Proposition 3.7 we can choose $\zeta \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$ to be the process $\zeta_{t}=-2 a \nu_{t}+\zeta_{t}^{\prime}$, where $\zeta^{\prime}$ is the process in $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$ such that

$$
\zeta_{t}^{\prime}=\mathbb{E}\left[-(2 \phi-h) Q_{T}^{B}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \eta_{s}-p Y_{s}-\left(h \mathrm{e}^{(t-s) p} p+2 r^{B}\right) Q_{s}^{B}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \quad \text { a.s. for a.e. } t
$$

# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

Hence for a.e. $t$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left[\zeta_{t}^{\gamma}\left\{-2 a \nu_{t}+\mathbb{E}\left[-(2 \phi-h) Q_{T}^{B}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \eta_{s}-p Y_{s}-\left(h \mathrm{e}^{(t-s) p} p+2 r^{B}\right) Q_{s}^{B}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]\right\}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\left|-2 a \nu_{t}+\mathbb{E}\left[-(2 \phi-h) Q_{T}^{B}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \eta_{s}-p Y_{s}-\left(h \mathrm{e}^{(t-s) p} p+2 r^{B}\right) Q_{s}^{B}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right| \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]\right|^{2}\right] .
\end{aligned}
$$

Then (3.17)) and (3.18) imply

$$
-2 a \nu_{t}+\mathbb{E}\left[-(2 \phi-h) Q_{T}^{B}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \eta_{s}-p Y_{s}-\left(h \mathrm{e}^{(t-s) p} p+2 r^{B}\right) Q_{s}^{B}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]=0 \quad \text { a.s. for a.e. } t
$$

(3.16) then follows.

Conversely, (3.16) implies (3.17) due to (3.18).

## 4 Nash Equilibria

In this section, we characterize the existence and uniqueness of Nash equilibria in a small time regime and then further characterize the equilibria as a system of FBSDEs.
Theorem 4.1. If the time horizon $T$ satisfies $C(T)<1$, where

$$
C(T):=T^{2} \max \left\{\begin{array}{c}
\left\|a^{-1}\right\|^{2}(2\|\phi\|+\|h\|)^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\left(\left\|b^{-1}\right\|^{2}+1\right)\|h\|^{2}+1 \\
\left\|a^{-1}\right\|^{2}(2\|\phi\|+2\|h\|)^{2}+4\left\|b^{-1}\right\|^{2}\|\psi\|^{2}+\frac{3}{2} \\
\frac{1}{2}\|p\|^{2}\left(\left\|a^{-1}\right\|^{2}+\left\|b^{-1}\right\|^{2}\right) \\
\frac{1}{2}\left\|a^{-1}\right\|^{2}\left(\|h\|\|p\|+2\| r^{B}\|\right)^{2} \\
2\left\|b^{-1}\right\|^{2}\left\|r^{I}\right\|^{2}
\end{array}\right\}
$$

then there exists a unique Nash equilibrium between the broker and the informed trader.
Proof. Suppose $C(T)$ defined in the statement of the theorem satisfies $C(T)<1$. Equip $\mathbb{T}:=\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2} \times \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2} \times \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2} \times$ $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2} \times \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$ with the norm

$$
\left\|\left(\nu, \eta, Y, Q^{B}, Q^{I}\right)\right\|_{\mathbb{T}}:=\left(\|\nu\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2}+\|\eta\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2}+\|Y\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2}+\left\|Q^{B}\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2}+\left\|Q^{I}\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}
$$

Then $(\mathbb{T},\|\cdot\|_{\mathbb{T}})$ is a Banach space. For $\Upsilon=\left(\nu, \eta, Y, Q^{B}, Q^{I}\right) \in \mathbb{T}$, define the quintuple $\Phi$ of processes in the following way: $\Phi_{., 1}(\Upsilon)$ is the element in $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$ such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Phi_{t, 1}(\Upsilon) \\
& =\frac{1}{2} a^{-1} \mathbb{E}\left[-(2 \phi-h)\left(q^{B}+\int_{0}^{T}\left(\nu_{s}-\eta_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right)+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \eta_{s}-p Y_{s}-\left(h \mathrm{e}^{(t-s) p} p+2 r^{B}\right) Q_{s}^{B}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

a.s. for a.e. $t \in[0, T] ; \Phi_{., 2}(\Upsilon)$ is the element in $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$ such that

$$
\Phi_{t, 2}(\Upsilon)=\frac{1}{2} b^{-1} \mathbb{E}\left[-2 \psi\left(q^{I}+\int_{0}^{T} \eta_{s} \mathrm{~d} s\right)+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right]
$$

a.s. for a.e. $t \in[0, T]$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Phi_{t, 3}(\Upsilon)=\mathrm{e}^{-t p} y+\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{e}^{(s-t) p} h \nu_{s} \mathrm{~d} s \\
& \Phi_{t, 4}(\Upsilon)=q^{B}+\int_{0}^{t}\left(\nu_{s}-\eta_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s, \quad \text { and } \\
& \Phi_{t, 5}(\Upsilon)=q^{I}+\int_{0}^{t} \eta_{s} \mathrm{~d} s
\end{aligned}
$$

# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

By Lemma 2.1, $\Phi$ is a map from $\mathbb{T}$ to itself. By Proposition 3.8 and Proposition 3.9, there exists a unique Nash equilibrium between the broker and the informed trader if $\Phi$ admits a unique fixed point, i.e., there exists a unique $\Upsilon^{*}=\left(\nu^{*}, Y^{*}, \eta^{*}, Q^{B *}, Q^{I *}\right) \in \mathbb{T}$ such that $\Phi\left(\Upsilon^{*}\right)=\Upsilon^{*}$. We next show that such a point does exist uniquely.
Take $\Upsilon=\left(\nu, Y, \eta, Q^{B}, Q^{I}\right) \in \mathbb{T}$ and $\hat{\Upsilon}=\left(\hat{\nu}, \hat{Y}, \hat{\eta}, \hat{Q}^{B}, \hat{Q}^{I}\right) \in \mathbb{T}$. Then for a.e. $t \in[0, T]$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left[\left|\Phi_{t, 1}(\Upsilon)-\Phi_{t, 1}(\hat{\Upsilon})\right|^{2}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\left|\frac{1}{2} a^{-1} \mathbb{E}\left[-(2 \phi-h) \int_{0}^{T}\left(\left(\nu_{s}-\hat{\nu}_{s}\right)-\left(\eta_{s}-\hat{\eta}_{s}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} s\right.\right. \\
& \left.\left.+\int_{t}^{T}\left(h\left(\eta_{s}-\hat{\eta}_{s}\right)-p\left(Y_{s}-\hat{Y}_{s}\right)-\left(h \mathrm{e}^{(t-s) p} p+2 r^{B}\right)\left(Q_{s}^{B}-\hat{Q}_{s}^{B}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} s \right] \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]\right|^{2}\right] \\
& \leq \frac{1}{2}\left\|a^{-1}\right\|^{2} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\|2 \phi-h\| \int_{0}^{T}\left|\nu_{s}-\hat{\nu}_{s}\right| \mathrm{d} s+(\|2 \phi-h\|+\|h\|) \int_{0}^{T}\left|\eta_{s}-\hat{\eta}_{s}\right| \mathrm{d} s\right.\right. \\
& \left.\left.+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\|p\| \| Y_{s}-\hat{Y}_{s}\right]+\left(\|h\|\|p\|+2\| r^{B}\|\right)\left|Q_{s}^{B}-\hat{Q}_{s}^{B}\right|\right) \mathrm{d} s\right)^{2}\right] \\
& \leq\left\|a^{-1}\right\|^{2} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\|2 \phi-h\|^{2}\left(\int_{0}^{T}\left|\nu_{s}-\hat{\nu}_{s}\right| \mathrm{d} s\right)^{2}+(\|2 \phi-h\|+\|h\|)^{2}\left(\int_{0}^{T}\left|\eta_{s}-\hat{\eta}_{s}\right| \mathrm{d} s\right)^{2}\right.\right. \\
& \left.\left.+\left(\int_{t}^{T}\|p\||Y_{s}-\hat{Y}_{s}\right| \mathrm{d} s\right)^{2}+\left(\int_{t}^{T}\left(\|h\|\|p\|+2\| r^{B}\|\right)\left|Q_{s}^{B}-\hat{Q}_{s}^{B}\right| \mathrm{d} s\right)^{2}\right)\right] \\
& \leq\left\|a^{-1}\right\|^{2} \mathbb{E}\left[\|2 \phi-h\|^{2} T \int_{0}^{T}\left|\nu_{s}-\hat{\nu}_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s+(\|2 \phi-h\|+\|h\|)^{2} T \int_{0}^{T}\left|\eta_{s}-\hat{\eta}_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s\right. \\
& \left.\left.+(T-t) \int_{0}^{T}\|p\|^{2}\left|Y_{s}-\hat{Y}_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s+(T-t) \int_{0}^{T}\left(\|h\|\|p\|+2\| r^{B}\|\right)^{2}\left|Q_{s}^{B}-\hat{Q}_{s}^{B}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s\right]\right] \\
& \leq\left\|a^{-1}\right\|^{2}\left(\|2 \phi-h\|^{2} T \| \nu-\hat{\nu}\|_{\mathbb{R}^{2}}^{2}+(\|2 \phi-h\|+\|h\|)^{2} T \| \eta-\hat{\eta}\|_{\mathbb{R}^{2}}^{2}\right. \\
& \left.\left.+(T-t) \|p\|^{2}\|Y-\hat{Y}\|_{\mathbb{R}^{2}}^{2}+(T-t)\left(\|h\|\|p\|+2\| r^{B}\|\right)^{2}\left\|Q^{B}-\hat{Q}^{B}\right\|_{\mathbb{R}^{2}}^{2}\right)\right,
\end{aligned}
$$

so

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|\Phi_{., 1}(\Upsilon)-\Phi_{., 1}(\hat{\Upsilon})\right\|_{\mathbb{R}^{2}}^{2}=\int_{0}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|\Phi_{t, 1}(\Upsilon)-\Phi_{t, 1}(\hat{\Upsilon})\right|^{2}\right] \mathrm{d} t \\
& \leq\left\|a^{-1}\right\|^{2}\left(\|2 \phi-h\|^{2} T^{2}\|\nu-\hat{\nu}\|_{\mathbb{R}^{2}}^{2}+(\|2 \phi-h\|+\|h\|)^{2} T^{2}\|\eta-\hat{\eta}\|_{\mathbb{R}^{2}}^{2}\right. \\
& \left.+\frac{T^{2}}{2}\|p\|^{2}\|Y-\hat{Y}\|_{\mathbb{R}^{2}}^{2}+\frac{T^{2}}{2}\left(\|h\|\|p\|+2\| r^{B}\|\right)^{2}\left\|Q^{B}-\hat{Q}^{B}\right\|_{\mathbb{R}^{2}}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|\Phi_{., 2}(\Upsilon)-\Phi_{., 2}(\hat{\Upsilon})\right\|_{\mathbb{R}^{2}}^{2} \\
& \leq\left\|b^{-1}\right\|^{2}\left(4\|\psi\|^{2} T^{2}\|\eta-\hat{\eta}\|_{\mathbb{R}^{2}}^{2}+\frac{T^{2}}{2}\left(\|h\|^{2}\|\nu-\hat{\nu}\|_{\mathbb{R}^{2}}^{2}+\|p\|^{2}\|Y-\hat{Y}\|_{\mathbb{R}^{2}}^{2}+4\| r^{I}\|^{2}\left\|Q^{I}-\hat{Q}^{I}\right\|_{\mathbb{R}^{2}}^{2}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We also have

$$
\left\|\Phi_{., 3}(\Upsilon)-\Phi_{., 3}(\hat{\Upsilon})\right\|_{\mathbb{R}^{2}}^{2}=\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{e}^{(s-t) p} h \nu_{s} \mathrm{~d} s\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} t\right] \leq \frac{T^{2}}{2}\|h\|^{2}\|\nu-\hat{\nu}\|_{\mathbb{R}^{2}}^{2}
$$

# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

$$
\left\|\Phi_{.4}(\Upsilon)-\Phi_{.4}(\hat{\Upsilon})\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2}=\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|\int_{0}^{t}\left(\nu_{s}-\hat{\nu}_{s}-\eta_{s}+\hat{\eta}_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} t\right] \leq T^{2}\left(\|\nu-\hat{\nu}\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2}+\|\eta-\hat{\eta}\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2}\right)
$$

and

$$
\left\|\Phi_{.5}(\Upsilon)-\Phi_{.5}(\hat{\Upsilon})\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2}=\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|\int_{0}^{t}\left(\eta_{s}-\hat{\eta}_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} t\right] \leq \frac{T^{2}}{2}\|\eta-\hat{\eta}\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2}
$$

Combing all the estimates gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|\Phi(\Upsilon)-\Phi(\hat{\Upsilon})\right\|_{\gamma}^{2} \leq T^{2}\left(\left\|a^{-1}\right\|^{2}\|2 \phi-h\|^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\left(\left\|b^{-1}\right\|^{2}+1\right)\|h\|^{2}+1\right)\|\nu-\hat{\nu}\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2} \\
& +T^{2}\left(\left\|a^{-1}\right\|^{2}\left(\|2 \phi-h\|+\|h\|\right)^{2}+4\left\|b^{-1}\right\|^{2}\|\psi\|^{2}+\frac{3}{2}\right)\|\eta-\hat{\eta}\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2} \\
& +\frac{1}{2} T^{2}\|p\|^{2}\left(\left\|a^{-1}\right\|^{2}+\left\|b^{-1}\right\|^{2}\right)\|Y-\bar{Y}\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2} \\
& +\frac{1}{2} T^{2}\left\|a^{-1}\right\|^{2}\left(\|h\|\|p\|+2\| r^{B}\|\right)^{2}\left\|Q^{B}-\hat{Q}^{B}\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2} \\
& +2 T^{2}\left\|b^{-1}\right\|^{2}\left\|r^{I}\right\|^{2}\left\|Q^{I}-\hat{Q}^{I}\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2} \\
& \leq C(T)\|\Upsilon-\bar{Y}\|_{\gamma}^{2},
\end{aligned}
$$

hence, $\Phi: \mathbb{T} \rightarrow \mathbb{T}$ is a contraction as $C(T)<1$. By Banach fixed point theorem, $\Phi$ admits a unique fixed point in $\mathbb{T}$, as desired.

Theorem 4.2. Let $\hat{\alpha} \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$ be the projection of $\alpha$ onto $\mathbb{G} .(\nu, \eta) \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2} \times \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$ is a Nash equilibrium between the broker and the trader if and only if there exist processes $Z, \hat{\eta}, \hat{Q}^{B}, \hat{Q}^{I}, Y, M^{B}, N^{B}, O^{B}, P^{B}, R^{B}$ in $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$, where $M^{B}, N^{B}, O^{B}, P^{B}, R^{B}$ are $\mathbb{G}$-martingales, and processes $Q^{B}, Q^{I}, M^{I}$ in $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{P}}^{2}$, where $M^{I}$ is an $\mathbb{F}$-martingale, such that these processes together solve the system of FBSDEs

$$
\begin{cases}\mathrm{d} \nu_{t}=-\frac{1}{2} a^{-1}\left[\left(\hat{\alpha}_{t}-(2 r^{B}+h p) \hat{Q}_{t}^{B}-p Y_{t}+h\left(\hat{\eta}_{t}+p Z_{t}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} t+\mathrm{d} M_{t}^{B}\right], & \nu_{T}=-\frac{1}{2} a^{-1}(2 \phi-h) \hat{Q}_{T}^{B} \\ \mathrm{~d} \eta_{t}=-\frac{1}{2} b^{-1}\left[\left(\alpha_{t}-2 r^{I} Q_{t}^{I}+h \nu_{t}-p Y_{t}\right) \mathrm{d} t+\mathrm{d} M_{t}^{I}\right], & \eta_{T}=-b^{-1} \psi Q_{T}^{I} \\ \mathrm{~d} Z_{t}=p\left(Z_{t}-\hat{Q}_{t}^{B}\right) \mathrm{d} t+\mathrm{d} N_{t}^{B}, & Z_{T}=0 \\ \mathrm{~d} \hat{\eta}_{t}=-\frac{1}{2} b^{-1}\left[\left(\hat{\alpha}_{t}-2 r^{I} \hat{Q}_{t}^{I}+h \nu_{t}-p Y_{t}\right) \mathrm{d} t+\mathrm{d} O_{t}^{B}\right], & \hat{\eta}_{T}=-b^{-1} \psi \hat{Q}_{T}^{I} \\ \mathrm{~d} \hat{Q}_{t}^{B}=\left(\nu_{t}-\hat{\eta}_{t}\right) \mathrm{d} t+\mathrm{d} P_{t}^{B}, & \hat{Q}_{T}^{B}=\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{T}\right] \\ \mathrm{d} \hat{Q}_{t}^{I}=\hat{\eta}_{t} \mathrm{~d} t+\mathrm{d} R_{t}^{B}, & \hat{Q}_{T}^{I}=\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{I} \mid \mathcal{G}_{T}\right]\end{cases}
$$

and

$$
\begin{cases}\mathrm{d} Q_{t}^{B}=\left(\nu_{t}-\eta_{t}\right) \mathrm{d} t, & Q_{0}^{B}=q^{B} \\ \mathrm{~d} Q_{t}^{I}=\eta_{t} \mathrm{~d} t, & Q_{0}^{I}=q^{I} \\ \mathrm{~d} Y_{t}=\left(h \nu_{t}-p Y_{t}\right) \mathrm{d} t, & Y_{0}=y\end{cases}
$$

Proof. We proof the statement first by showing that from a Nash equilibria we can construct a set of processes that satisfies the FBSDE system, and second show that a set of processes satisfying the FBSDE is a Nash equilibria.
Nash $\Rightarrow$ FBSDEs: Suppose $(\nu, \eta) \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2} \times \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{P}}^{2}$ is a Nash equilibrium between the broker and the trader. Define processes $Q^{B}, Q^{I}$ in $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{P}}^{2}$, and $Y$ in $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$ (see Lemma 2.1) by

$$
Q_{t}^{B}=q^{B}+\int_{0}^{t}\left(\nu_{s}-\eta_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s, \quad Q_{t}^{I}=q^{I}+\int_{0}^{t} \eta_{s} \mathrm{~d} s, \quad Y_{t}=\mathrm{e}^{-t p} y+\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{e}^{(s-t) p} h \nu_{s} \mathrm{~d} s
$$

By Proposition 3.9, for a.e. $t \in[0, T]$, almost surely we have

$$
2 a \nu_{t}=\mathbb{E}\left[-(2 \phi-h) Q_{T}^{B}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \eta_{s}-p Y_{s}-\left(h \mathrm{e}^{(t-s) p} p+2 r^{B}\right) Q_{s}^{B}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]
$$

# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

$$
\begin{aligned}
= & \mathbb{E}\left[-(2 \phi-h) Q_{T}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]+\int_{t}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[\alpha_{s}+h \eta_{s}-p Y_{s}-\left(h \mathrm{e}^{(t-s) p} p+2 r^{B}\right) Q_{s}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \mathrm{d} s \\
= & \mathbb{E}\left[-(2 \phi-h) Q_{T}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]+\int_{t}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{E}\left[\alpha_{s}+h \eta_{s}-p Y_{s}-\left(h \mathrm{e}^{(t-s) p} p+2 r^{B}\right) Q_{s}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right] \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \mathrm{d} s \\
= & \mathbb{E}\left[-(2 \phi-h) Q_{T}^{B}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\hat{\alpha}_{s}+h \mathbb{E}\left[\eta_{s} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right]-p Y_{s}-\left(h \mathrm{e}^{(t-s) p} p+2 r^{B}\right) \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{s}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right]\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\
= & \mathbb{E}\left[-(2 \phi-h) Q_{T}^{B}+\int_{0}^{T}\left(\hat{\alpha}_{s}+h \mathbb{E}\left[\eta_{s} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right]-p Y_{s}-2 r^{B} \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{s}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right]\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\
& -h \mathrm{e}^{t p} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{-s p} p \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{s}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right] \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]-\int_{0}^{t}\left(\hat{\alpha}_{s}+h \mathbb{E}\left[\eta_{s} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right]-p Y_{s}-2 r^{B} \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{s}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right]\right) \mathrm{d} s \\
& +h \mathrm{e}^{t p} \int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{e}^{-s p} p \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{s}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right] \mathrm{d} s
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $\hat{\eta} \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$ and $\hat{Q}^{B} \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$ be the projections of $\eta$ and $Q^{B}$ onto $\mathbb{G}$, respectively. Define processes $\tilde{N}$ and $Z$ in $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$ by

$$
\tilde{N}_{t}=\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{-s p} p \hat{Q}_{s}^{B} \mathrm{~d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \quad \text { and } \quad Z_{t}=\mathrm{e}^{t p}\left(\tilde{N}_{t}-\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{e}^{-s p} p \hat{Q}_{s}^{B} \mathrm{~d} s\right)
$$

Then $M^{B}$ and $\tilde{N}$ are $\mathbb{G}$-martingales, which are càd-làg. By generalized Itô's formula and the fact that a càd-làg path has at most countably many jumps (so $u$ - can be replaced by $u$ when integrating with respect to $\mathrm{d} u$ ), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
Z_{t}^{(i)}= & Z_{T}^{(i)}-\sum_{j=1}^{K} \int_{t}^{T}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{K} p_{i, k}\left[\mathrm{e}^{u p}\right]^{k, j}\left(\tilde{N}_{u-}^{(j)}-\int_{0}^{u}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-s p} p \hat{Q}_{s}^{B}\right]^{j} \mathrm{~d} s\right)-\left[\mathrm{e}^{u p}\right]^{i, j}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-u p} p \hat{Q}_{u}^{B}\right]^{j}\right) \mathrm{d} u \\
& -\sum_{j=1}^{K} \int_{t}^{T}\left[\mathrm{e}^{u p}\right]^{i, j} \mathrm{~d} \tilde{N}_{u}^{(j)}-\sum_{t<u \leq T}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{K}\left[\mathrm{e}^{u p}\right]^{i, j}\left(\tilde{N}_{u}^{(j)}-\tilde{N}_{u-}^{(j)}\right)-\sum_{j=1}^{K}\left[\mathrm{e}^{u p}\right]^{i, j}\left(\tilde{N}_{u}^{(j)}-\tilde{N}_{u-}^{(j)}\right)\right) \\
= & Z_{T}^{(i)}-\int_{t}^{T}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{K} p_{i, k} \sum_{j=1}^{K}\left[\mathrm{e}^{u p}\right]^{k, j}\left(\tilde{N}_{u-}^{(j)}-\int_{0}^{u}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-s p} p \hat{Q}_{s}^{B}\right]^{j} \mathrm{~d} s\right)-\left[p \hat{Q}_{u}^{B}\right]^{i}\right) \mathrm{d} u-\sum_{j=1}^{K} \int_{t}^{T}\left[\mathrm{e}^{u p}\right]^{i, j} \mathrm{~d} \tilde{N}_{u}^{(j)} \\
= & Z_{T}^{(i)}-\left[\int_{t}^{T} p\left(Z_{u}-\hat{Q}_{u}^{B}\right) \mathrm{d} u\right]^{i}-\sum_{j=1}^{K} \int_{t}^{T}\left[\mathrm{e}^{u p}\right]^{i, j} \mathrm{~d} \tilde{N}_{u}^{(j)}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
Z_{T}=\mathrm{e}^{T p}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{-s p} p \hat{Q}_{s}^{B} \mathrm{~d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{T}\right]-\int_{0}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{-s p} p \hat{Q}_{s}^{B} \mathrm{~d} s\right)=0
$$

Define the $\mathbb{R}^{K}$-valued $\mathbb{G}$-local martingale $N^{B}$ by $N_{t}^{B,(i)}=\sum_{j=1}^{K} \int_{0}^{t}\left[\mathrm{e}^{u p}\right]^{i, j} \mathrm{~d} \tilde{N}_{u}^{(j)}$. Then

$$
Z_{t}=-\int_{t}^{T} p\left(Z_{u}-\hat{Q}_{u}^{B}\right) \mathrm{d} u-\left(N_{T}^{B}-N_{t}^{B}\right)
$$

As each $\tilde{N}^{(j)}$ is a $\mathbb{G}$-martingale with

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left|\tilde{N}_{t}^{(j)}\right|^{2}\right] \leq \mathbb{E}\left[\left|\tilde{N}_{t}\right|^{2}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\left|\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{-s p} p \hat{Q}_{s}^{B} \mathrm{~d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]\right|^{2}\right] \leq \mathbb{E}\left[\left|\int_{0}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{-s p} p \hat{Q}_{s}^{B} \mathrm{~d} s\right|^{2}\right] \leq T\|p\|^{2}\left\|\hat{Q}^{B}\right\|_{\mathbb{H}}^{2}
$$

for all $t \in[0, T]$, we have $\mathbb{E}\left[\left\langle\tilde{N}^{(j)}\right\rangle_{t}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\left|\tilde{N}_{t}^{(j)}\right|^{2}\right]$ for all $t \in[0, T]$. Let $E=\sup _{u \in[0, T], i, j}\left|\left[\mathrm{e}^{u p}\right]^{i, j}\right|^{2}$. Then

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|\left[\mathrm{e}^{u p}\right]^{i, j}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d}\left\langle\tilde{N}^{(j)}\right\rangle_{u}\right] \leq E \mathbb{E}\left[\left\langle\tilde{N}^{(j)}\right\rangle_{T}\right]=E \mathbb{E}\left[\left|\tilde{N}_{T}^{(j)}\right|^{2}\right] \leq E T\|p\|^{2}\left\|\hat{Q}^{B}\right\|_{\mathbb{H}}^{2}<\infty
$$

# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

so each $\left(\int_{0}^{t}\left[\mathrm{e}^{u p}\right]^{i, j} \mathrm{~d} \tilde{N}_{u}^{(j)}\right)_{t \in[0, T]}$ is a $\mathbb{G}$-martingale with

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|\int_{0}^{t}\left[\mathrm{e}^{u p}\right]^{i, j} \mathrm{~d} \tilde{N}_{u}^{(j)}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} t\right]=\int_{0}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|\int_{0}^{t}\left[\mathrm{e}^{u p}\right]^{i, j} \mathrm{~d} \tilde{N}_{u}^{(j)}\right|^{2}\right] \mathrm{d} t & =\int_{0}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{t}\left|\left[\mathrm{e}^{u p}\right]^{i, j}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d}\left\langle\tilde{N}^{(j)}\right\rangle_{u}\right] \mathrm{d} t \\
& \leq E T^{2}\|p\|^{2}\left\|\hat{Q}^{B}\right\|_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Consequently, $N^{B}$ is a $\mathbb{G}$-martingale that lies in $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$. We further define the $\mathbb{G}$-martingale $M^{B} \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$ by

$$
M_{t}^{B}=-\mathbb{E}\left[-(2 \phi-h) Q_{T}^{B}+\int_{0}^{T}\left(\hat{\alpha}_{s}+h \hat{\eta}_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{B} \hat{Q}_{s}^{B}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]+h N_{t}^{B}
$$

For $\hat{Q}^{B}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{Q}_{t}^{B} & =\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{B}-\int_{t}^{T}\left(\nu_{s}-\eta_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{B}-\int_{t}^{T}\left(\nu_{s}-\mathbb{E}\left[\eta_{s} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right]\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{B}-\int_{0}^{T}\left(\nu_{s}-\bar{\eta}_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]+\int_{0}^{t}\left(\nu_{s}-\bar{\eta}_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s
\end{aligned}
$$

Define $\mathbb{G}$-martingale $P^{B} \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$ by $P_{t}^{B}=\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{B}-\int_{0}^{T}\left(\nu_{s}-\bar{\eta}_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]$. Then $\hat{Q}^{B}$ satisfies

$$
\hat{Q}_{t}^{B}=P_{t}^{B}+\int_{0}^{t}\left(\nu_{s}-\bar{\eta}_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s=P_{T}^{B}+\int_{0}^{T}\left(\nu_{s}-\bar{\eta}_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s-\int_{t}^{T}\left(\nu_{s}-\bar{\eta}_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s-\int_{t}^{T} \mathrm{~d} P_{s}^{B}
$$

where

$$
P_{T}^{B}+\int_{0}^{T}\left(\nu_{s}-\bar{\eta}_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s=\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{B}-\int_{0}^{T}\left(\nu_{s}-\bar{\eta}_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{T}\right]+\int_{0}^{T}\left(\nu_{s}-\bar{\eta}_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s=\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{T}\right]
$$

With these processes identified, it follows from (4.4) that

$$
\begin{aligned}
2 a \nu_{t}= & -\int_{0}^{t}\left(\hat{\alpha}_{s}+h \hat{\eta}_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{B} \hat{Q}_{s}^{B}\right) \mathrm{d} s-h Z_{t}-M_{t}^{B}+h N_{t}^{B} \\
= & -M_{T}^{B}+h N_{T}^{B}-\int_{0}^{T}\left(\hat{\alpha}_{s}+h \bar{\eta}_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{B} \hat{Q}_{s}^{B}\right) \mathrm{d} s \\
& +\int_{t}^{T}\left(\hat{\alpha}_{s}+h \bar{\eta}_{s}-p Y_{s}-\left(2 r^{B}+h p\right) \hat{Q}_{s}^{B}+h p Z_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s+\left(M_{T}^{B}-M_{t}^{B}\right) \\
= & -(2 \phi-h) \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{T}\right] \\
& +\int_{t}^{T}\left(\hat{\alpha}_{s}+h \bar{\eta}_{s}-p Y_{s}-\left(2 r^{B}+h p\right) \hat{Q}_{s}^{B}+h p Z_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s+\left(M_{T}^{B}-M_{t}^{B}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Furthermore, by Proposition 3.8, for a.e. $t \in[0, T]$, almost surely we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
2 b \eta_{t} & =\mathbb{E}\left[-2 \psi Q_{T}^{I}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[-2 \psi Q_{T}^{I}+\int_{0}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right]-\int_{0}^{t}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s
\end{aligned}
$$

therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
2 b \bar{\eta}_{t} & =\mathbb{E}\left[-2 \psi Q_{T}^{I}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[-2 \psi Q_{T}^{I}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\hat{\alpha}_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{s}^{I} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right]\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

$$
\begin{aligned}
= & \mathbb{E}\left[-2 \psi Q_{T}^{I}+\int_{0}^{T}\left(\hat{\alpha}_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{s}^{I} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right]\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\
& \quad-\int_{0}^{t}\left(\hat{\alpha}_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{s}^{I} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right]\right) \mathrm{d} s
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $\hat{Q}^{I} \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{Q}}^{2}$ be the projection of $\hat{Q}^{I}$ onto $\mathbb{G}$. Define process $\mathbb{F}$-martingale $M^{I} \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$, and $\mathbb{G}$-martingale $O^{B} \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{Q}}^{2}$ by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& M_{t}^{I}=-\mathbb{E}\left[-2 \psi Q_{T}^{I}+\int_{0}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right], \quad \text { and } \\
& O_{t}^{B}=-\mathbb{E}\left[-2 \psi Q_{T}^{I}+\int_{0}^{T}\left(\hat{\alpha}_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} \hat{Q}_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, from (4.5), we have that

$$
\begin{aligned}
2 b \eta_{t} & =-M_{t}^{I}-\int_{0}^{t}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s \\
& =-M_{T}^{I}-\int_{0}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s+\left(M_{T}^{I}-M_{t}^{I}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and, from (4.6), we have that

$$
\begin{aligned}
2 b \hat{\eta}_{t} & =-O_{t}^{B}-\int_{0}^{t}\left(\hat{\alpha}_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} \hat{Q}_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s \\
& =-O_{T}^{B}-\int_{0}^{T}\left(\hat{\alpha}_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} \hat{Q}_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\hat{\alpha}_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} \hat{Q}_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s+\left(O_{T}^{B}-O_{t}^{B}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& -M_{T}^{I}-\int_{0}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[-2 \psi Q_{T}^{I}+\int_{0}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{F}_{T}\right]-\int_{0}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s=-2 \psi Q_{T}^{I}
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& -O_{T}^{B}-\int_{0}^{T}\left(\hat{\alpha}_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} \hat{Q}_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[-2 \psi Q_{T}^{I}+\int_{0}^{T}\left(\hat{\alpha}_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} \hat{Q}_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{T}\right]-\int_{0}^{T}\left(\hat{\alpha}_{s}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}-2 r^{I} \hat{Q}_{s}^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} s \\
& =-2 \psi \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{I} \mid \mathcal{G}_{T}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally,

$$
\hat{Q}_{t}^{I}=\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{I}-\int_{t}^{T} \eta_{s} \mathrm{~d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{I}-\int_{t}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[\eta_{s} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right] \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{I}-\int_{0}^{T} \hat{\eta}_{s} \mathrm{~d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]+\int_{0}^{t} \hat{\eta}_{s} \mathrm{~d} s
$$

where $R^{B} \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{Q}}^{2}$ defined by $R_{t}^{B}=\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{I}-\int_{0}^{T} \hat{\eta}_{s} \mathrm{~d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]$ is a $\mathbb{G}$-martingale. Hence

$$
\hat{Q}_{t}^{I}=R_{t}^{B}+\int_{0}^{t} \hat{\eta}_{s} \mathrm{~d} s=R_{T}^{B}+\int_{0}^{T} \hat{\eta}_{s} \mathrm{~d} s-\int_{t}^{T} \hat{\eta}_{s} \mathrm{~d} s-\int_{t}^{T} \mathrm{~d} R_{s}^{B}
$$

where

$$
R_{T}^{B}+\int_{0}^{T} \hat{\eta}_{s} \mathrm{~d} s=\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{I}-\int_{0}^{T} \hat{\eta}_{s} \mathrm{~d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{T}\right]+\int_{0}^{T} \hat{\eta}_{s} \mathrm{~d} s=\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{I} \mid \mathcal{G}_{T}\right]
$$

# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

Putting these results together, we find that the FBSDEs (4.2)-(4.3) are solved by these processes. Hence, we have shown that starting with a $(\nu, \eta) \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2} \times \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$ being a Nash equilibrium between the broker and the trader, the corresponding processes defined above satisfy the required system of FBSDEs.
FBSDEs $\Rightarrow$ Nash: Conversely, assume that the collection of processes in the statement of the theorem satisfy the FBSDEs (4.2)-(4.3). By integrating $\eta$ and using the terminal conditions, we may write

$$
2 b \eta_{t}=-2 \psi Q_{T}^{I}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s+M_{T}^{I}-M_{t}^{I}
$$

As $\eta$ is $\mathbb{F}$-adapted and $M^{I}$ is an $\mathbb{F}$-martingale,

$$
2 b \eta_{t}=2 b \mathbb{E}\left[\eta_{t} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[-2 \psi Q_{T}^{I}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right]
$$

hence, by Proposition 3.8, $\eta$ maximizes $J^{I}(\nu, \cdot)$ over $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$. Furthermore, this implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\eta_{t} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] & =-\frac{1}{2} b^{-1} \mathbb{E}\left[2 \psi Q_{T}^{I}-\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\
& =-\frac{1}{2} b^{-1}\left[2 \psi \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{I} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]-\int_{t}^{T}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\alpha_{s} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]-2 r^{I} \mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{s}^{I} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right] \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]\right) \mathrm{d} s\right] \\
& =-\frac{1}{2} b^{-1} \mathbb{E}\left[2 \psi Q_{T}^{I}-\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}-2 r^{I} \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{s}^{I} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right]+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

The dynamics of $\hat{\eta}, \hat{Q}^{I}, Q^{I}$ implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\hat{\eta}_{t} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] & =-\frac{1}{2} b^{-1} \mathbb{E}\left[2 \psi \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{I} \mid \mathcal{G}_{T}\right]-\int_{t}^{T}\left(\hat{\alpha}_{s}-2 r^{I} \hat{Q}_{s}^{I}+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s+O_{T}^{B}-O_{t}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\
& =-\frac{1}{2} b^{-1} \mathbb{E}\left[2 \psi Q_{T}^{I}-\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}-2 r^{I} \mathbb{E}\left[\hat{Q}_{s}^{I} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right]+h \nu_{s}-p Y_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\
\mathbb{E}\left[\hat{Q}_{t}^{I} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] & =\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{I} \mid \mathcal{G}_{T}\right]-\int_{t}^{T} \hat{\eta}_{s} \mathrm{~d} s-R_{T}^{B}+R_{t}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{I}-\int_{t}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[\hat{\eta}_{s} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right] \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{t}^{I} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{I}-\int_{t}^{T} \eta_{s} \mathrm{~d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{I}-\int_{t}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[\eta_{s} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right] \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]
$$

Hence

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\eta_{t}-\hat{\eta}_{t} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]=-b^{-1} r^{I} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{s}^{I}-\hat{Q}_{s}^{I} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right] \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]
$$

and

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{t}^{I}-\hat{Q}_{t}^{I} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]=-\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[\eta_{s}-\hat{\eta}_{s} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right] \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]
$$

For $(\gamma, \xi) \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2} \times \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$, consider the pair of processes $\Psi(\gamma, \xi)$ defined by

$$
\Psi(\gamma, \xi)_{t}=\left(-b^{-1} r^{I} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T} \xi_{s} \mathrm{~d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right],-\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T} \gamma_{s} \mathrm{~d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]\right)
$$

# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

$\Psi$ defines a linear map from $\mathbb{H}_{G}^{2} \times \mathbb{H}_{G}^{2}$ to itself because for every $C>0$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{C t}\left|-b^{-1} r^{I} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T} \xi_{s} \mathrm{~d} s\right| \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} t\right] & \leq\left\|b^{-1} r^{I}\right\|^{2} \int_{0}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{C t} \mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T}\left|\xi_{s}\right| \mathrm{d} s\right| \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]^{2}\right] \mathrm{d} t \\
& \leq\left\|b^{-1} r^{I}\right\|^{2} \int_{0}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{C t} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\int_{t}^{T}\left|\xi_{s}\right| \mathrm{d} s\right)^{2}\right] \mathrm{d} t \\
& \leq T\left\|b^{-1} r^{I}\right\|^{2} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{C t} \int_{t}^{T}\left|\xi_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s \mathrm{~d} t\right] \\
& =T\left\|b^{-1} r^{I}\right\|^{2} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|\xi_{s}\right|^{2} \int_{0}^{s} \mathrm{e}^{C t} \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} s\right] \\
& =T\left\|b^{-1} r^{I}\right\|^{2} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|\xi_{s}\right|^{2} \frac{\mathrm{e}^{C s}-1}{C} \mathrm{~d} s\right] \\
& \leq \frac{T\left\|b^{-1} r^{I}\right\|^{2}}{C} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{C s}\left|\xi_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

and, similarly,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{C t}\left|-\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T} \gamma_{s} \mathrm{~d} s\right| \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} t\right] \leq \frac{T}{C} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{C s}\left|\gamma_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s\right]
$$

By choosing $C>T \max \left\{\left\|b^{-1} r^{I}\right\|^{2}, 1\right\}$, these two estimates also imply $\Psi$ is a contraction on $\mathbb{H}_{G}^{2} \times \mathbb{H}_{G}^{2}$ when equipped with the norm

$$
\|(\gamma, \xi)\|_{\mathbb{H}_{G}^{2} \times \mathbb{H}_{G}^{2}}^{2}:=\|\gamma\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}, C}^{2}+\|\xi\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}, C}^{2}
$$

where $\|\cdot\|_{\mathbb{R}, C}$ is the norm on $\mathbb{H}_{G}^{2}$ defined by

$$
\|\zeta\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}, C}^{2}:=\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{C t}\left|\zeta_{t}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} t\right]
$$

which is equivalent to $\|\cdot\|_{\mathbb{R}}$. Therefore, 0 is the unique fixed point of $\Psi$, which in particular implies

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\eta_{t} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\hat{\eta}_{t} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]
$$

Next, the dynamics of $Q^{B}$ and $\dot{Q}^{B}$ implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\dot{Q}_{t}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] & =\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{T}\right]-\int_{t}^{T}\left(\nu_{s}-\dot{\eta}_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s-P_{T}^{B}+P_{t}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]-\int_{t}^{T}\left(\nu_{s}-\mathbb{E}\left[\dot{\eta}_{s} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right]\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]-\int_{t}^{T}\left(\nu_{s}-\mathbb{E}\left[\eta_{s} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right]\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{B}-\int_{t}^{T}\left(\nu_{s}-\eta_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[Q_{t}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

The dynamics of $\nu$ and $Z$ implies
$2 a \nu_{t}$

# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =-(2 \phi-h) \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{T}\right]+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\hat{\alpha}_{s}-\left(2 r^{B}+h p\right) \hat{Q}_{s}^{B}-p Y_{s}+h \hat{\eta}_{s}+h p Z_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s+\left(M_{T}^{B}-M_{t}^{B}\right) \\
& =-(2 \phi-h) \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{T}\right]+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\hat{\alpha}_{s}-2 r^{B} \hat{Q}_{s}^{B}-p Y_{s}+h \hat{\eta}_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s-h Z_{t}-h\left(N_{T}^{B}-N_{t}^{B}\right)+\left(M_{T}^{B}-M_{t}^{B}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Moreover, the dynamics of $Z$ implies it is a càd-làg $\mathbb{G}$-semimartingale, therefore, the generalized Itô's formula implies the $i$ th component of $\mathrm{e}^{-t p} Z_{t}$ satisfies

$$
\begin{aligned}
{\left[\mathrm{e}^{-t p} Z_{t}\right]^{i}=} & \sum_{j}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-t p}\right]^{i, j} Z_{t}^{(j)} \\
= & \sum_{j} \int_{t}^{T}\left(\sum_{k} p_{i, k}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-u p}\right]^{k, j} Z_{u}^{(j)}-\left[\mathrm{e}^{-u p}\right]^{i, j} \sum_{k} p_{j, k}\left(Z_{u}^{(k)}-\hat{Q}_{u}^{B,(k)}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} u \\
& -\sum_{j} \int_{t}^{T}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-u p}\right]^{i, j} \mathrm{~d} N_{u}^{B,(j)} \\
= & \int_{t}^{T}\left(\left[p \mathrm{e}^{-u p} Z_{u}\right]^{i}-\left[\mathrm{e}^{-u p} p\left(Z_{u}-\hat{Q}_{u}^{B}\right)\right]^{i}\right) \mathrm{d} u-\sum_{j} \int_{t}^{T}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-u p}\right]^{i, j} \mathrm{~d} N_{u}^{B,(j)} \\
= & \int_{t}^{T}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-u p} p \hat{Q}_{u}^{B}\right]^{i} \mathrm{~d} u-\sum_{j} \int_{t}^{T}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-u p}\right]^{i, j} \mathrm{~d} N_{u}^{B,(j)}
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $N^{B}$ is a $\mathbb{G}$-martingale that lies in $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$, similarly as above, the process $\left(\int_{0}^{t}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-s p}\right]^{i, j} \mathrm{~d} N_{s}^{B,(j)}\right)_{t \in[0, T]}$ is a $\mathbb{G}$ martingale, thus

$$
\left[\mathrm{e}^{-t p} Z_{t}\right]^{i}=\mathbb{E}\left[\left[\mathrm{e}^{-t p} Z_{t}\right]^{i} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T}\left[\mathrm{e}^{-u p} p \hat{Q}_{u}^{B}\right]^{i} \mathrm{~d} u \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]
$$

As $\nu$ is $\mathbb{G}$-adapted and $M^{B}$ is a $\mathbb{G}$-martingale, (4.8), (4.9), (4.10), and (4.11) gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
2 a \nu_{t} & =2 a \mathbb{E}\left[\nu_{t} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\
& =-(2 \phi-h) \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T}\left(\hat{\alpha}_{s}-p Y_{s}+h \hat{\eta}_{s}-2 r^{B} \hat{Q}_{s}^{B}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]-h \mathrm{e}^{t p} \mathrm{e}^{-t p} Z_{t} \\
& =-(2 \phi-h) \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T}\left(\hat{\alpha}_{s}-p Y_{s}+h \hat{\eta}_{s}-2 r^{B} \hat{Q}_{s}^{B}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]-h \mathrm{e}^{t p} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{-s p} p \hat{Q}_{u}^{B} \mathrm{~d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\
& =-(2 \phi-h) \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T}\left(\hat{\alpha}_{s}-p Y_{s}+h \hat{\eta}_{s}-2 r^{B} \hat{Q}_{s}^{B}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]-\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T} h \mathrm{e}^{(t-s) p} p \hat{Q}_{s}^{B} \mathrm{~d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\
& =-(2 \phi-h) \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}-p Y_{s}+h \hat{\eta}_{s}-\left(h \mathrm{e}^{(t-s) p} p+2 r^{B}\right) \hat{Q}_{s}^{B}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\
& =-(2 \phi-h) \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}-p Y_{s}+h \mathbb{E}\left[\hat{\eta}_{s} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right]-\left(h \mathrm{e}^{(t-s) p} p+2 r^{B}\right) \mathbb{E}\left[\hat{Q}_{s}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right]\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\
& =-(2 \phi-h) \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}-p Y_{s}+h \mathbb{E}\left[\eta_{s} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right]-\left(h \mathrm{e}^{(t-s) p} p+2 r^{B}\right) \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{s}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{s}\right]\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\
& =-(2 \phi-h) \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{B} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}-p Y_{s}+h \eta_{s}-\left(h \mathrm{e}^{(t-s) p} p+2 r^{B}\right) Q_{s}^{B}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, by Proposition 3.9, $\nu$ maximizes $J^{B}(\cdot, \eta)$ over $\mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$. By definition, $(\nu, \eta)$ is a Nash equilibrium between the broker and the informed trader.

# 5 Perturbation Analysis 

The FBSDE system (4.2), or equivalently (3.13) and (3.16) jointly, that characterizes the Nash equilibria is challenging to solve in generality. In this section, we provide a perturbation analysis that allows us to approximate the solution to arbitrary accuracy in terms of the strength of the transient impact parameter $h$. The approximation we develop is represented as an asymptotic series, where each term in the series admits a closed form solution in terms of the previous coefficients in the expansion. Specifically we obtain a representation of the form

$$
\eta_{t}=\sum_{m=0}^{M} h^{m} \eta_{t}^{m}+R_{t}^{\eta, M, h}, \quad \text { and } \quad \nu_{t}=\sum_{m=0}^{M} h^{m} \nu_{t}^{m}+R_{t}^{\nu, M, h}
$$

where we provide explicit representations of $\left(\eta_{t}^{m}, \nu_{t}^{m}\right)_{m}$. Moreover, we prove that the error terms, $R_{t}^{\eta, M, h}$ and $R_{t}^{\nu, M, h}$, from truncating the series at a given order $M$, are both $o(M)$. While the results in this section could be generalized to arbitrary dimensions, in the remainder of this section, for simplicity, we assume $D=K=1$ (i.e., the broker and informed trader are dealing in a single asset) to avoid commutativity issues.

To this end, the following lemma provides the FBSDEs that each term in the series satisfies, and proves that a unique solution exists, as well as provides the explicit form of the solution.
Lemma 5.1. Assume $C(T)$ defined in (4.1) satisfies $C(T)<1$. Then there is a unique sequence $\left(\left(\eta^{m}, Q^{I, m}\right)\right)_{m=0}^{\infty}$ in $\mathbb{H}_{2}^{2} \times \mathbb{H}_{2}^{2}$ and a unique sequence $\left(\left(\nu^{m}, Q^{B, m}\right)\right)_{m=0}^{\infty}$ in $\mathbb{H}_{G}^{2} \times \mathbb{H}_{2}^{2}$ that solve the following equations recursively:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\{\begin{array}{c}
\eta_{t}^{0}=\frac{1}{2 b} \mathbb{E}\left[-2 \psi Q_{T}^{I, 0}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}-p \mathrm{e}^{-s p} y-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I, 0}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right] \\
Q_{t}^{I, 0}=q^{I}+\int_{0}^{t} \eta_{s}^{0} \mathrm{~d} s
\end{array}\right. \\
& \left\{\begin{array}{c}
\nu_{t}^{0}=\frac{1}{2 a} \mathbb{E}\left[-2 \phi Q_{T}^{B, 0}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\alpha_{s}-p \mathrm{e}^{-s p} y-2 r^{B} Q_{s}^{B, 0}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\
Q_{t}^{B, 0}=q^{B}+q^{I}-Q_{t}^{I, 0}+\int_{0}^{t} \nu_{s}^{0} \mathrm{~d} s
\end{array}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

and for $m \geq 1$,

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
\eta_{t}^{m} & =\frac{1}{2 b} \mathbb{E}\left[-2 \psi Q_{T}^{I, m}+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\nu_{s}^{m-1}-p \int_{0}^{s} \mathrm{e}^{(u-s) p} \nu_{u}^{m-1} \mathrm{~d} u-2 r^{I} Q_{s}^{I, m}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right] \\
Q_{t}^{I, m} & =\int_{0}^{t} \eta_{s}^{m} \mathrm{~d} s
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
\nu_{t}^{m}=\frac{1}{2 a} \mathbb{E}[ & -2 \phi Q_{T}^{B, m}+Q_{T}^{B, m-1} \\
& \left.+\int_{t}^{T}\left(\eta_{s}^{m-1}-p \int_{0}^{s} \mathrm{e}^{(u-s) p} \nu_{u}^{m-1} \mathrm{~d} u-\mathrm{e}^{(t-s) p} p Q_{s}^{B, m-1}-2 r^{B} Q_{s}^{B, m}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\
Q_{t}^{B, m}=-Q_{t}^{I, m}+\int_{0}^{t} \nu_{s}^{m} \mathrm{~d} s
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

Moreover, they admit the explicit recursive formulae:

$$
\begin{aligned}
Q_{t}^{I, 0} & =q^{I}-\frac{\psi}{b} \int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{u}^{t} \mathrm{f}_{s}^{I} \mathrm{~d} s+\int_{u}^{T} \mathrm{f}_{s}^{I} \mathrm{~d} s} q^{I} \mathrm{~d} u+\frac{1}{2 b} \int_{0}^{t} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{u}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{u}^{t} \mathrm{f}_{s}^{I} \mathrm{~d} s+\int_{u}^{T} \mathrm{f}_{s}^{I} \mathrm{~d} s}\left(\alpha_{r}-p \mathrm{e}^{-r p} y-2 r^{I} q^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} r \mid \mathcal{F}_{u}\right] \mathrm{d} u \\
\eta_{t}^{0} & =-\frac{\psi}{b} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{t}^{T} \mathrm{f}_{s}^{I} \mathrm{~d} s} q^{I}+\frac{1}{2 b} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{t}^{u} \mathrm{f}_{s}^{I} \mathrm{~d} s}\left(\alpha_{u}-p \mathrm{e}^{-u p} y-2 r^{I} q^{I}\right) \mathrm{d} u \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right]+\mathrm{f}_{t}^{I}\left(Q_{t}^{I, 0}-q^{I}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

$$
\begin{aligned}
Q_{t}^{B, 0}= & q^{B}+q^{I}-Q_{t}^{I, 0}-\frac{\phi}{a} \int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{u}^{t} \mathfrak{f}_{s}^{B} \mathrm{~d} s+\int_{u}^{T} \mathfrak{f}_{s}^{B} \mathrm{~d} s} \mathbb{E}\left[q^{B}+q^{I}-Q_{T}^{I, 0} \mid \mathcal{G}_{u}\right] \mathrm{d} u \\
& +\frac{1}{2 a} \int_{0}^{t} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{u}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{u}^{t} \mathfrak{f}_{s}^{B} \mathrm{~d} s+\int_{u}^{T} \mathfrak{f}_{s}^{B} \mathrm{~d} s}\left(\alpha_{r}-p \mathrm{e}^{-r p} y-2 r^{B}\left(q^{B}+q^{I}-Q_{r}^{I, 0}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} r \mid \mathcal{G}_{u}\right] \mathrm{d} u \\

& +\frac{1}{2 a} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{t}^{u} \mathfrak{f}_{s}^{B} \mathrm{~d} s}\left(\alpha_{u}-p \mathrm{e}^{-u p} y-2 r^{B}\left(q^{B}+q^{I}-Q_{u}^{I, 0}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} u \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]+\mathfrak{f}_{t}^{B}\left(Q_{t}^{B, 0}-q^{B}-q^{I}+Q_{t}^{I, 0}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and for $m \geq 1$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
Q_{t}^{I, m}= & \frac{1}{2 b} \int_{0}^{t} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{u}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{u}^{t} \mathfrak{f}_{s}^{I} \mathrm{~d} s+\int_{u}^{T} \mathfrak{f}_{s}^{B} \mathrm{~d} s}\left(\nu_{r}^{m-1}-p \int_{0}^{r} \mathrm{e}^{(s-r) p} \nu_{s}^{m-1} \mathrm{~d} s\right) \mathrm{d} r \mid \mathcal{F}_{u}\right] \mathrm{d} u \\

Q_{t}^{B, m}= & -Q_{t}^{I, m} \frac{1}{2 a} \int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{u}^{t} \mathfrak{f}_{s}^{B} \mathrm{~d} s+\int_{u}^{T} \mathfrak{f}_{s}^{B} \mathrm{~d} s} \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{B, m-1}+2 \phi Q_{T}^{I, m} \mid \mathcal{G}_{u}\right] \mathrm{d} u \\

& +\frac{1}{2 a} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{t}^{u} \mathfrak{f}_{s}^{B} \mathrm{~d} s}\left(\eta_{u}^{m-1}-p\left(\int_{0}^{u} \mathrm{e}^{(s-u) p} \nu_{s}^{m-1} \mathrm{~d} s+Q_{u}^{B, m-1}\right)+2 r^{B} Q_{u}^{I, m}\right) \mathrm{d} u \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\

\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathfrak{f}_{s}^{I}:=f\left(s, \frac{\varphi}{\tau}, \frac{\dot{\tau}}{\tau}\right), \mathfrak{f}_{s}^{B}:=f\left(s, \frac{\dot{\varphi}}{\tau}, \frac{\dot{\tau}}{\tau}\right)$ and

$$
f(t, c, k):= \begin{cases}0, & k=0, c=0 \\ -\left(T-t+c^{-1}\right)^{-1}, & k=0, c>0 \\ -\sqrt{k} \frac{(\sqrt{k}+c)-(\sqrt{k}-c) \mathrm{e}^{2 \sqrt{k}-(T-t)}}{(\sqrt{k}+c)-(\sqrt{k}-c) \mathrm{e}^{-2 \sqrt{k}(T-t)}}, & k>0\end{cases}

Proof. Note that every equation is of the form

$$

\varphi_{t}=\gamma_{t}+\int_{0}^{t} \beta_{s} \mathrm{~d} s
\end{array}\right.
$$

where $\mathbb{Y}=\left(\mathcal{Y}_{t}\right)_{t \in[0, T]}$ is either $\mathbb{F}$ or $\mathbb{G},(c, k)$ is either $\left(\frac{\phi}{a}, \frac{r^{B}}{a}\right)$ or $\left(\frac{\varphi}{b}, \frac{\tau^{I}}{b}\right), \Xi$ is a known random variable, $A, B, \gamma$ are known $\mathbb{F}$-progressively measurable processes such that $B$ and $\gamma$ are finite-variation processes, $\beta$ is an unknown $\mathbb{Y}$-progressively measurable processes, and $\varphi$ is an unknown $\mathbb{F}$-progressively measurable processes.

# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

Consider the map $\Gamma: \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{Y}}^{2} \times \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{Y}}^{2} \rightarrow \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{Y}}^{2} \times \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{Y}}^{2}$ defined by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Gamma_{t, 1}(\beta, \varphi)=\mathbb{E}\left[-c\left(\gamma_{T}+\int_{0}^{T} \beta_{s} \mathrm{~d} s\right)+\Xi+\int_{t}^{T}\left(A_{s}-k \varphi_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s \mid \mathcal{Y}_{t}\right]-\mathrm{e}^{t p} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T} B_{s} \mathrm{~d} s \mid \mathcal{Y}_{t}\right] \\
& \Gamma_{t, 2}(\beta, \varphi)=\gamma_{t}+\int_{0}^{t} \beta_{s} \mathrm{~d} s
\end{aligned}
$$

Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|\Gamma_{\cdot, 1}(\beta, \varphi)-\Gamma_{\cdot, 1}(\hat{\beta}, \hat{\varphi})\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2}=\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|\mathbb{E}\left[-c \int_{0}^{T}\left(\beta_{s}-\hat{\beta}_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s-k \int_{t}^{T}\left(\varphi_{s}-\hat{\varphi}_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right] \mathcal{Y}_{t}\right]\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} t\right] \\
& \leq \int_{0}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[\left|-c \int_{0}^{T}\left(\beta_{s}-\hat{\beta}_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s-k \int_{t}^{T}\left(\varphi_{s}-\hat{\varphi}_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right|^{2}\right] \mathrm{d} t \\
& \leq T \mathbb{E}\left[\left(c \int_{0}^{T}\left|\beta_{s}-\hat{\beta}_{s}\right| \mathrm{d} s+k \int_{0}^{T}\left|\varphi_{s}-\hat{\varphi}_{s}\right| \mathrm{d} s\right)^{2}\right] \\
& \leq 2 T^{2} \mathbb{E}\left[c^{2} \int_{0}^{T}\left|\beta_{s}-\hat{\beta}_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s+k^{2} \int_{0}^{T}\left|\varphi_{s}-\hat{\varphi}_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s\right] \\
& \leq 2 T^{2}\left(c^{2}\|\beta-\hat{\beta}\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2}+k^{2}\|\varphi-\hat{\varphi}\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\Gamma_{\cdot, 2}(\beta, \varphi)-\Gamma_{\cdot, 2}(\hat{\beta}, \hat{\varphi})\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2}=\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|\int_{0}^{t}\left(\beta_{s}-\hat{\beta}_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} t\right] & \leq \mathbb{E}\left[T\left(\int_{0}^{T}\left|\beta_{s}-\hat{\beta}_{s}\right| \mathrm{d} s\right)^{2}\right] \\
& \leq \mathbb{E}\left[T^{2} \int_{0}^{T}\left|\beta_{s}-\hat{\beta}_{s}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} s\right]=T^{2}\|\beta-\hat{\beta}\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus

$$
\left\|\Gamma_{\cdot, 1}(\beta, \varphi)-\Gamma_{\cdot, 1}(\hat{\beta}, \hat{\varphi})\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2}+\left\|\Gamma_{\cdot, 2}(\beta, \varphi)-\Gamma_{\cdot, 2}(\hat{\beta}, \hat{\varphi})\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2} \leq T^{2} \max \left\{2 c^{2}+1,2 k^{2}\right\}\left(\|\beta-\hat{\beta}\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2}+\|\varphi-\hat{\varphi}\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}^{2}\right)
$$

Since $T^{2} \max \left\{2 c^{2}+1,2 k^{2}\right\} \leq C(T)$, we see that $\Gamma$ is a contraction, which admits a unique fixed point, which is the unique solution to (5.5).

To obtain an explicit form of the solution, we use the same method as in the proof of Theorem 4.2 to write down the FBSDE

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\mathrm{d} \beta_{t}=-\left(D_{t}-k \varphi_{t}\right) \mathrm{d} t+\mathrm{d} M_{t}, & \beta_{T}=-c \varphi_{T}+\mathbb{E}\left[\Xi \mid \mathcal{Y}_{T}\right] \\
\mathrm{d} \varphi_{t}=\mathrm{d} \gamma_{t}+\beta_{t} \mathrm{~d} t, & \varphi_{0}=\gamma_{0}
\end{array}
$$

where

$$
D_{t}=\mathbb{E}\left[A_{t}+p \mathrm{e}^{t p} \int_{t}^{T} B_{s} \mathrm{~d} s-\mathrm{e}^{t p} B_{t} \mid \mathcal{Y}_{t}\right]
$$

and $M$ is a $\mathbb{Y}$-martingale. We solve this FBSDE using the ansatz

$$
\beta_{t}=\ell_{t}+f(t)\left(\varphi_{t}-\gamma_{t}\right)
$$

where $\ell$ is a $\mathbb{Y}$-progressively measurable process and $f$ is a deterministic function. Differentiating (5.8) and using (5.6b) give

$$
\mathrm{d} \beta_{t}=\mathrm{d} \ell_{t}+f^{\prime}(t)\left(\varphi_{t}-\gamma_{t}\right) \mathrm{d} t+f(t) \beta_{t} \mathrm{~d} t
$$

# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\mathrm{d} \ell_{t}+f^{\prime}(t)\left(\varphi_{t}-\gamma_{t}\right) \mathrm{d} t+f(t)\left(\ell_{t}+f(t)\left(\varphi_{t}-\gamma_{t}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} t \\
& =\mathrm{d} \ell_{t}+\left(f(t) \ell_{t}-f(t)^{2} \gamma_{t}-f^{\prime}(t) \gamma_{t}\right) \mathrm{d} t+\left(f^{\prime}(t)+f(t)^{2}\right) \varphi_{t} \mathrm{~d} t
\end{aligned}
$$

Due to this and (5.6a), it suffices to solve the ODE

$$
f^{\prime}(t)=-f(t)^{2}+k, \quad f(T)=-c
$$

and the BSDE

$$
\mathrm{d} \ell_{t}=-\left(D_{t}-k \gamma_{t}+f(t) \ell_{t}\right) \mathrm{d} t+\mathrm{d} M_{t}, \quad \ell_{T}=\mathbb{E}\left[-c \gamma_{T}+\Xi \mid \mathcal{Y}_{T}\right]
$$

The ODE (5.9) admits the solution

$$
f(t)= \begin{cases}0, & k=0, c=0 \\ \frac{1}{t-T-\frac{k}{c}}, & k=0, c>0 \\ \sqrt{k} \frac{(\sqrt{k}-c) \mathrm{e}^{2 \sqrt{k}(t-T)}-(\sqrt{k}+c)}{(\sqrt{k}-c) \mathrm{e}^{2 \sqrt{k}(t-T)}+(\sqrt{k}+c)}, & k>0\end{cases}
$$

To solve (5.10), use the generalized Itô's formula to write

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{e}^{\int_{0}^{t} f(s) \mathrm{d} s} \ell_{t} \\
& =\mathrm{e}^{\int_{0}^{T} f(s) \mathrm{d} s} \mathbb{E}\left[-c \gamma_{T}+\Xi \mid \mathcal{Y}_{T}\right]-\int_{t}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{0}^{\alpha} f(s) \mathrm{d} s} f(u) \ell_{u} \mathrm{~d} u-\int_{t}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{0}^{\alpha} f(s) \mathrm{d} s} \mathrm{~d} \ell_{u} \\
& =\mathrm{e}^{\int_{0}^{T} f(s) \mathrm{d} s} \mathbb{E}\left[-c \gamma_{T}+\Xi \mid \mathcal{Y}_{T}\right]+\int_{t}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{0}^{\alpha} f(s) \mathrm{d} s}\left(D_{u}-k \gamma_{u}\right) \mathrm{d} u-\int_{t}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{0}^{\alpha} f(s) \mathrm{d} s} \mathrm{~d} M_{u}
\end{aligned}
$$

therefore,

$$
\ell_{t}=\mathrm{e}^{\int_{t}^{T} f(s) \mathrm{d} s} \mathbb{E}\left[-c \gamma_{T}+\Xi \mid \mathcal{Y}_{t}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{0}^{\alpha} f(s) \mathrm{d} s}\left(D_{u}-k \gamma_{u}\right) \mathrm{d} u \mid \mathcal{Y}_{t}\right]
$$

Having obtained $\ell$ and $f$, we substitute (5.8) into (5.6b) to get the ODE

$$
\mathrm{d}\left(\varphi_{t}-\gamma_{t}\right)=\left(\ell_{t}+f(t)\left(\varphi_{t}-\gamma_{t}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} t, \quad \varphi_{0}=\gamma_{0}
$$

whose solution is

$$
\varphi_{t}=\gamma_{t}+\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{u}^{t} f(s) \mathrm{d} s} \ell_{u} \mathrm{~d} u
$$

Finally, combining (5.7), (5.8), (5.11), and (5.12) gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
\beta_{t}=\mathrm{e}^{\int_{t}^{T} f(s) \mathrm{d} s} \mathbb{E}\left[-c \gamma_{T}+\Xi \mid \mathcal{Y}_{t}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{t}^{\alpha} f(s) \mathrm{d} s}\left(A_{u}+p \mathrm{e}^{u p} \int_{u}^{T} B_{s} \mathrm{~d} s-\mathrm{e}^{u p} B_{u}-\right.\right. & \left.\left.\mathrm{d} u \mid \mathcal{Y}_{t}\right] \\
& +f(t)\left(\varphi_{t}-\gamma_{t}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Next, we prove that we may approximate the exact solution of the full FBSDE system by a polynomial series with coefficients given by Lemma 5.1.
Theorem 5.2. Let $h_{0} \geq 0$ and fix $T>0$ such that $C\left(T, h_{0}\right)<1$, where $C(T, h)$ is the quantity $C(T)$ defined in (4.1) for a given $h$. For every nonnegative integer $M$ and every $h \in\left[0, h_{0}\right]$, there is $R^{\eta, M, h} \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{F}}^{2}$ and $R^{\nu, M, h} \in \mathbb{H}_{\mathbb{G}}^{2}$ such that

$$
\eta_{t}=\sum_{m=0}^{M} h^{m} \eta_{t}^{m}+R_{t}^{\eta, M, h}, \quad \nu_{t}=\sum_{m=0}^{M} h^{m} \nu_{t}^{m}+R_{t}^{\nu, M, h}
$$

and

$$
\lim _{h \rightarrow 0^{+}}\left\|\frac{R^{\eta, M, h}}{h^{M}}\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}=0 \quad \text { and } \quad \lim _{h \rightarrow 0^{+}}\left\|\frac{R^{\nu, M, h}}{h^{M}}\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}=0
$$

where $\eta^{m}$ and $\nu^{m}$ are processes defined in Lemma 5.1.

& \left\|\frac{\Psi_{.1}^{h}(\Upsilon)}{h^{M}}\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}} \leq h C \\
& +\frac{1}{2 a h^{M}}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left|\mathbb{E}\left[-(2 \phi-h) \int_{0}^{T}\left(\zeta_{u}-\xi_{u}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right.\right.\right.\right. \\
& \left.\left.\quad+\int_{t}^{T}\left(h \xi_{s}-p \gamma_{s}-\left(h \mathrm{e}^{(t-s) p} p+2 r^{B}\right) \kappa_{s}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right] \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} t \mid\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& \leq h C+\frac{1}{2 a h^{M}} C^{\prime}\left(\int_{0}^{T} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\int_{0}^{T}\left(\left|\zeta_{s}\right|+\left|\xi_{s}\right|+\left|\gamma_{s}\right|+\left|\kappa_{s}\right|\right) \mathrm{d} s\right)^{2}\right] \mathrm{d} t\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& \leq h C+\frac{T}{a h^{M}} C^{\prime}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\int_{0}^{T}\left(\left|\zeta_{s}\right|^{2}+\left|\xi_{s}\right|^{2}+\left|\gamma_{s}\right|^{2}+\left|\kappa_{s}\right|^{2}\right) \mathrm{d} s\right]\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& \leq h C+\frac{T}{a} C^{\prime}\left\|\frac{\Upsilon}{h^{M}}\right\|_{\mathbb{T}} \text {. }
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly,

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left\|\frac{\Psi_{.2}^{h}(\Upsilon)}{h^{M}}\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}} \leq h C+\frac{T}{b} \max \left\{2 \psi, h, p, 2 r^{I}\right\}\left\|\frac{\Upsilon}{h^{M}}\right\|_{\mathbb{T}} \\
\left\|\frac{\Psi_{.3}^{h}(\Upsilon)}{h^{M}}\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}} \leq T h\left\|\frac{\Upsilon}{h^{M}}\right\|_{\mathbb{T}}, \quad\left\|\frac{\Psi_{.4}^{h}(\Upsilon)}{h^{M}}\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}} \leq T\left\|\frac{\Upsilon}{h^{M}}\right\|_{\mathbb{T}}, \quad \text { and } \quad\left\|\frac{\Psi_{.5}^{h}(\Upsilon)}{h^{M}}\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}} \leq \sqrt{2} T\left\|\frac{\Upsilon}{h^{M}}\right\|_{\mathbb{T}} .
\end{gathered}
$$

Therefore, given a family $\left(\Upsilon^{h}\right)_{h}$ of elements of $\mathbb{T}$,

$$
\lim _{h \rightarrow 0^{+}}\left\|\frac{\Upsilon^{h}}{h^{M}}\right\|_{\mathbb{T}}=0 \quad \Longrightarrow \quad \lim _{h \rightarrow 0^{+}}\left\|\frac{\Psi^{h}\left(\Upsilon^{h}\right)}{h^{M}}\right\|_{\mathbb{T}}=0
$$

Next, take $h \in\left[0, h_{0}\right]$ and let $\Upsilon^{h, 0}=0$ and $\Upsilon^{h, n}=\Psi^{h}\left(\Upsilon^{h, n-1}\right)$ for $n \geq 1$. The Banach fixed point theorem states that the sequence $\left(\Upsilon^{h, n}\right)_{n}$ converges to the unique fixed point $\Upsilon^{h, *}$ of $\Psi^{h}$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$ and provides the following estimation:

$$
\left\|\Upsilon^{h, *}-\Upsilon^{h, n}\right\|_{\mathbb{T}} \leq \frac{C(T, h)^{n / 2}}{1-C(T, h)^{1 / 2}}\left\|\Upsilon^{h, 1}-\Upsilon^{h, 0}\right\|_{\mathbb{T}}, \quad \forall n
$$

By (5.13), for every $n, \lim _{h \rightarrow 0^{+}}\left\|\frac{\Upsilon^{h, n}}{h^{M}}\right\|_{\mathbb{T}}=0$. It follows that for a fixed $n_{0}$,

$$
\left\|\frac{\Upsilon^{h, *}}{h^{M}}\right\|_{\mathbb{T}} \leq\left\|\frac{\Upsilon^{h, *}}{h^{M}}-\frac{\Upsilon^{h, n_{0}}}{h^{M}}\right\|_{\mathbb{T}}+\left\|\frac{\Upsilon^{h, n_{0}}}{h^{M}}\right\|_{\mathbb{T}} \leq \frac{C(T, h)^{n_{0} / 2}}{1-C(T, h)^{1 / 2}}\left(\left\|\frac{\Upsilon^{h, 1}}{h^{M}}\right\|_{\mathbb{T}}+\left\|\frac{\Upsilon^{h, 0}}{h^{M}}\right\|_{\mathbb{T}}\right. \text {. }
$$

Therefore,

$$
\lim _{h \rightarrow 0^{+}}\left\|\frac{\Upsilon^{h, *}}{h^{M}}\right\|_{\mathbb{T}}=0
$$

In particular, this implies the first two components of $\Upsilon^{h, *}, R^{\nu, M, h}$ and $R^{q, M, h}$, satisfy

$$
\lim _{h \rightarrow 0^{+}}\left\|\frac{R^{q, M, h}}{h^{M}}\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}=0, \quad \lim _{h \rightarrow 0^{+}}\left\|\frac{R^{\nu, M, h}}{h^{M}}\right\|_{\mathbb{H}^{2}}=0
$$

as desired.

# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

To gain some intuition of the these solutions, let us set the initial inventory levels to zero, i.e., $q^{I}=q^{B}=0$, the initial transient impact to zero, i.e., $y=0$, and the running penalty to zero, i.e., $r^{B}=r^{I}=0$. In this setting, the informed trader's trading rate is

$$
\eta_{t}^{0}=\mathfrak{f}_{t}^{I} Q_{t}^{I, 0}+\frac{1}{2 b} \int_{t}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{t}^{\alpha} \mathfrak{f}_{s}^{\prime} \mathrm{d} s} \mathbb{E}\left[\alpha_{u} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right] \mathrm{d} u, \quad Q_{t}^{I, 0}=\int_{0}^{t} \eta_{u}^{0} \mathrm{~d} u
$$

This mirrors the results of [8], where the first term is interpreted as the Almgren-Chriss solution [2] and the second term is a correction due to the trading signal. Moving to the broker's trading rate, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\nu_{t}^{0} & =\mathfrak{f}_{t}^{B}\left(Q_{t}^{B, 0}+Q_{t}^{I, 0}\right)+\frac{1}{2 a} \int_{t}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{t}^{\alpha} \mathfrak{f}_{s}^{\prime \prime} \mathrm{d} s} \mathbb{E}\left[\alpha_{u} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \mathrm{d} u+\frac{\sigma}{a} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{t}^{\alpha} \mathfrak{f}_{s}^{\prime \prime} \mathrm{d} s} \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{I, 0} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\
Q_{t}^{B, 0} & =\int_{0}^{t}\left(\nu_{u}^{0}-\eta_{u}^{0}\right) \mathrm{d} u
\end{aligned}
$$

The first two terms are analogous to the informed trader's strategy, i.e., there is an Almgren-Chriss term that is corrected by the trading signal - however, the Broker has less information and must filter the trading signal using their filtration $\mathcal{G}$. Moreover, there is an additional correction that depends on the broker's expectation of the informed trader's inventory process. These trading rates are the exact equilibrium when there is no transient impact and mimics in the setting when $h=0$ (i.e., no transient impact), these form the exact solution in the setting when there is no transient impact.

Moving to the higher order terms, we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
\eta_{t}^{m}= & \mathfrak{f}_{t}^{I} Q_{t}^{I, m}+\frac{1}{2 b} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{t}^{\alpha} \mathfrak{f}_{s}^{\prime} \mathrm{d} s}\left(\nu_{u}^{m-1}-p \int_{0}^{u} \mathrm{e}^{(s-u) p} \nu_{s}^{m-1} \mathrm{~d} s\right) \mathrm{d} u \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right] \\
\nu_{t}^{m}= & \mathfrak{f}_{t}^{B}\left(Q_{t}^{B, m}+Q_{t}^{I, m}\right)+\frac{1}{2 a} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{t}^{T} \mathfrak{f}_{s}^{\prime \prime} \mathrm{d} s} \mathbb{E}\left[Q_{T}^{B, m-1}+2 \phi Q_{T}^{I, m} \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\
& +\frac{1}{2 a} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{t}^{\alpha} \mathfrak{f}_{s}^{\prime \prime} \mathrm{d} s}\left(\eta_{u}^{m-1}-p\left(\int_{0}^{u} \mathrm{e}^{(s-u) p} \nu_{s}^{m-1} \mathrm{~d} s+Q_{u}^{B, m-1}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} u \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right] \\
& +\frac{\nu^{2}}{2 a} \mathbb{E}\left[\int_{t}^{T} \int_{u}^{T} \mathrm{e}^{\int_{t}^{\alpha} \mathfrak{f}_{s}^{\prime \prime} \mathrm{d} s+(u-r) p} Q_{r}^{B, m-1} \mathrm{~d} r \mathrm{~d} u \mid \mathcal{G}_{t}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

The first term in each expression is an Almgren-Chriss like term, however, it utilizes the shadow inventory corresponding to the appropriate order of the approximation. Further, for the informed trader, the second term corrects the Almgren-Chriss terms by a deviation in the previous order's trading rate and its induced transient impact. The broker's third term is of a similar nature - but projected onto their own filtration. The broker's second term accounts for the expected informed trader's inventory using the broker's filtration and corrected from the previous order's inventory. Finally the fourth term is a correction due to transient impact of the broker's previous order's inventory.

## 6 Conclusion

We presented a setting where a broker and informed trader trade multiple assets. The informed trader has superior information through a trading signal while the broker can offload inventory to a centralized exchanged. We prove that a Nash equilibria exists if and only if a particular system of FBSDEs have a solution and further prove, in a small time setting, that the system of FBSDEs does indeed have a unique solution. The system of FBSDEs contains differing filtrations, which is one of the key characteristics of our problem setting. Furthermore, while we cannot solve the FBSDE system in closed-form, we are able to approximate the solution to arbitrary order in the impact of trading and provide closed-form expressions for each term in this series. Moreover, we prove the remainder terms from truncating the series at order $M$ are $o(M)$.

There are several avenues left for future work, e.g., extending the existence and uniqueness result from small time to all time. This may require further restrictions on the model parameters, the trading signal, or martingale component

# Broker-Trader Partial Information Nash Equilibria 

of the price. The transient impact may be generalized to an arbitrary kernel. It would also be interesting to investigate the setting with multiple informed traders with differing information sets. Finally, for practical purposes, it would be useful to develop a deep learning algorithm to approximate the FBSDE system.

abstract:
We study partial information Nash equilibrium between a broker and an
informed trader. In this setting, the informed trader, who possesses knowledge
of a trading signal, trades multiple assets with the broker in a dealer market.
Simultaneously, the broker offloads these assets in a lit exchange where their
actions impact the asset prices. The broker, however, only observes aggregate
prices and cannot distinguish between underlying trends and volatility. Both
the broker and the informed trader aim to maximize their penalized expected
wealth. Using convex analysis, we characterize the Nash equilibrium and
demonstrate its existence and uniqueness. Furthermore, we establish that this
equilibrium corresponds to the solution of a nonstandard system of
forward-backward stochastic differential equations (FBSDEs) that involves the
two differing filtrations. For short enough time horizons, we prove that a
unique solution of this system exists. Finally, under quite general
assumptions, we show that the solution to the FBSDE system admits a polynomial
approximation in the strength of the transient impact to arbitrary order, and
prove that the error is controlled.
